24 Resolutions A resolution के is also a binding measure available to members and Ministers to discuss a matter of interest to the public .
Unlike motions in general the forms of resolutions are given in the Rules of Procedure of both the Houses.
Effect of Motions or Resolutions adopted by the House By voting on a motion or a resolution the House declares its opinion on the subject and it becomes an order of the House .
As far as their effect is concerned resolutions passed by the Parliament fall in the following categories :
Resolutions expressing merely an opinion of the House are not binding on the government .
Whether it is a matter of practice or not to indulge in such resolutions depends entirely on the discretion of the government .
Resolutions adopted by the House in matters concerning its own proceedings are binding and have the force of law .
Their validity cannot be challenged in courts .
Resolutions having a statutory effect - if adopted are binding on the government and have the force of law .

Notice of no - confidence motion can also be withdrawn by members concerned by sending letters of withdrawal signed by all the signatories to the notice before the item is taken up in the House .
In that case the tern is not mentioned in or brought before the House .
Rajya Sabha has no power to think of a motion of no - confidence because the government under the Constitution is collectively responsible to the directly elected Lok Sabha .
A censure motion is distinct from a no - confidence motion .
The motion of no - confidence does not indicate the reasons on which it is based but a censure motion must specify such reasons or charges and it is moved for the specific purpose of सरकार the government for certain policies and actions .
A censure motion is presented to the Council of Ministers or against a minister or against some of the ministers in opposition to any of their policy and the failure of any minister or of his is resented or regret by the House .
The motion should be specific and self - explanatory so as to record the reasons for censure precisely and precisely .
The Speaker ' s decision whether the motion is in order or not for any reason is final .
No leave of the House is required to move a censure motion .

Category B : Bills containing provisions involving expenditure from the Consolidated Fund .

Besides there is a slight procedural difference in the passage of Money Bills and Financial Bills through both the Houses .

Committee on Private Members' Bills and Resolutions : This Committee of the Lok Sabha consists of 15 members with the Deputy Speaker as its Chairman .
The Committee thus performs the same function in relation to Private Members' Bills and Resolutions as the Business Advisory Committee does in regard to government business .
There is no such Committee in the Rajya Sabha .
The Committee on the absence of members from the sittings of the House provides in the Constitution that if any of the two Houses are absent a member of the House for a period of 60 days from all the sittings of the House without permission .
In order to facilitate the Lok Sabha constituted a Committee consisting of 15 members to consider requests from members to absent from the House .
In the Rajya Sabha such matters are considered by the House itself .
The functions of the Committee are to consider all vacancies received from members for permission from the sittings of the House ( and ( 2 ) to investigate every case where a member has not been satisfied or barred from the sittings of the House .
The Committee also performs such other functions in respect of the attendance of members of the House as may be assigned to it by the Speaker from time to time .
Committee on Rules : Each House has a Rules Committee .
In the Lok Sabha the Rules Committee consists of 15 members including the Speaker who is the ex officio Chairman of the Committee .
In the Rajya Sabha the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman are 16 members of the Committee .
Suggestions for amendments or additions to the Rules can be made by any member of the House minister or the Committee itself .
The Committee thus acts as an Ombudsman or Public Grievances Committee .
The privileges are enjoyed by the members of each House of Parliament individually and collectively to the House indicating certain privileges and rights without which the House and its members cannot discharge their functions effectively.
When a question of breach of privilege arises even though the House is competent to deal with it it is generally referred to the Committee of Privileges existing in either House for examination investigation and reporting .
The Committee of Privileges is constituted generally every year by the Presiding Officers of the respective Houses .
It has 15 members in Lok Sabha and 10 members in Rajya Sabha .
The functions of the Committee are of a semi - judicial nature and it is vested with wide powers .
Although its findings are subject to the ultimate decision of the House it enjoys the latter ' s confidence and its recommendations are seldom rejected .
The Committee plays an important role in safeguarding the powers and prestige of the Parliament and of the members .
Committee on Information Technology and Public Grievances
In order to monitor the implementation of such assurances each House of Parliament has constituted a Committee on Government assurances .
The Committee keeps a regular watch to ensure that the Government implementing its recommendations .
Through its reports the Committee has tried to control and regulate the vast discretionary powers enjoyed by the administration with the main objective of protecting the citizens against any excess or abuse of power .
Late Shri Mavalankar the first Speaker of Indian Parliament held that the Committee on Subordinate Legislation is the सदन of the duties of the House and keeps the administration within bounds intended by Parliament .
The Committee on Papers Laid on the Table : At every session the government lays before the Parliament its statements statements statements statements reports and papers either in pursuance of constitutional provisions or in reply to questions or to inform the members of Parliament on various matters .
While some of these reports / papers stand referred to various parliamentary committees including the Committee on Subordinate Legislation a bulk of them remain to be examined in detail by the Committee on Papers Laid on the Table which is constituted by either House of Parliament .
In the Lok Sabha the Committee consists of 15 members while in the Rajya Sabha it has 10 members .
The Committee examines all the papers laid on the Table and reports to the House in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution under which the paper is placed on the Table of the House , if any found अधीन .
Thus the Committee seeks in general to enforce parliamentary control over the administration in areas where it was not in operation till it was constituted in 1975 .
The Committee on Welfare of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes provides several safeguards for the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes and the machinery to watch their implementation .
The Commissioner of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes का regular reports to the President regarding the welfare of the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes which are accommodated in Parliament and confirmed to the recommendations made by the Commissioner of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes .
The possibility of a close scrutiny by a Parliamentary Committee in itself exercise a salutary effect on the administration .
Many an act of negligence nepotism and waste are not committed for the simple fear that they may be looked into and exposed to public gaze by a Parliamentary Committee .
There is no doubt that the Committees of the Lok Sabha have proved a helpful adjunct to the Indian political system .
By consistent vigilance and fair and constructive assessment of the functioning of the Government Departments the Committees have made a distinct contribution to the effective working of the Parliament and have played a crucial role in generally strengthening parliamentary institutions in the country .

This marked the end of his outward activities .
As if in token of this in the next month November 1873 he removed the lighted lamp from his room and placed it outside .

Before the Forty - second Amendment the only mention of the word 'secular' in the Constitution was in article 25 ( 2 ) wherein State had been empowered to regulate or restrict any लौकिक associated with religious conduct .
Obviously here the connotation of 'secular' was' non - लौकिक or pertaining to matters other than purely religious .
The Forty - second Constitution Amendment Act which added the word secular did not attempt to define it .
It was however felt that the addition had to be felt only to approve and explain the fact which was believed to have existed as a basic feature of the Constitution .
The founding fathers tried to provide for the fullest representation by साक्षरता all the vast adult population of the country without any literacy division of income tax or males .
There is no hereditary ruler and the head of the state is elected by the people for a certain period .
It is usually called the President of the Republic .
Democratic republic may therefore broadly mean a State with an elected head and a government of the people .
All citizens are equal in the eyes of law and there is no privileged class and all public offices are open to every citizen without any distinction based on race caste creed sex or sex .
The membership of the Commonwealth India chose to remain a Commonwealth member even though it did not sign any of its prestige as a sovereign or as a Republic .
In fact it was the Commonwealth which was transformed.
In this positive connotation liberty would mean freedom of the individual to do what one likes.
Liberty of thought , faith and worship as elaborated in the fundamental rights part of the Constitution should be so regulated as not to endanger the security of the State public interest etc. .
Leaders of the French Revolution believed that all men were equal in the eyes of law .

Apart from this every citizen is equally eligible to enjoy all public office honours and positions strictly according to his / her talents only .

Where India was the old name and represented the first expression of the consciousness of the unity and integrity of the country India was the modern name from which India was known all over the world .
As a member of the United Nations also it was called India and all international agreements were entered in that name .
Both the names therefore had strong claims .
Finally the name 'India that is India " was adopted as a happy compromise .
India is a " Union ; the purpose of laying stress was to bring to light the fact that it was not the result of any bargaining or agreement between the constituent units but a clear declaration of the Constituent Assembly which had its power and authority .
No State could therefore secede from the Union nor could it suo की vary its territory as laid down in the First Schedule to the Constitution .
Article 2 provides that Parliament shall by law grant access to or establish new States in the Union of India on such terms and conditions as it deems fit .
The latest addition was that of the State of Sikkim by the 35th and 36वें Constitutional Amendments in 1974 and 1975 .
This was done at the request of the Sikkim Assembly and with the approval of the people of Sikkim .
Under article 3 Parliament is empowered to form a new State by separating a part of the territory of a State or by uniting two or more States or parts of States or by uniting any territory to a part of any State .
It may increase or decrease the area of a State and can also alter the boundaries or even the name of a State .
There is thus no guarantee of the territorial integrity or continued existence of a State .
But at the same time it has been held that the Parliament ' s power to diminish the area of any State does not include the contributions of the Indian territory to a foreign State .
( exchange of trade unions and बस्तियों in respect of बस्तियों AIR 1950 SC विनियम ) .
So we may say that India is an indestructible Union of राज्यों states .
He symbolizes that a person has absolute political membership of the state : he is his permanent allegiance to the state and that he is " widely accepted by the state to join the political system .
Citizenship provides certain rights - values duties and privileges .
All public offices are open to the citizen .
The right to vote and certain fundamental rights are available only to citizens and citizens have obligations like paying taxes defending the nation etc .
Citizenship may also be viewed as the legal relationship between the individual and the state under which the individual pledges his loyalty to the State and the State offers its protection to the individual .
This relationship is regulated by national law and recognized by international law .
On 26 November 1949 the Constituent Assembly adopted the Constitution and at once brought into force articles 5 to 9 relating to citizenship .
Until then those of us who lived in British India were under the Crown and were thus British subjects .
The partition of India and massive migrations created stupendous problems for citizenship determination .
Citizenship provisions in the Constitution - articles 5 to 11 - gave the Constitution Drafting Committee the maximum headache and took a large number of drafts and more than two years to be finalized.
Still in the Constitution only laid down the law regarding who would be the citizens of India at the time of the commencement of the Constitution .
It did not provide for the mode of acquisition and termination of citizenship .
Article 11 said that Parliament could regulate the right of citizenship by law .
Under Article 5 - 8 a person who was born in India was given the citizenship to any one of the following caste at the time of the commencement of the Constitution : i . e . who was born in India and not more than पाकिस्तान .
Thus the provisions for Citizenship at the commencement of the Constitution ( e . ) on the basis of domicile ( ii ) came from Pakistan and ( iii ) and the citizenship of Indians residing abroad .
Domicile - Domicile is an important criterion for citizenship of a country .
Raza v. State of Bombay ( AIR 1966 SC 1966 ) .
Article 5 provides that if a person resident in the territory of India lives on the commencement of the Constitution ( i . e . a person who has been a citizen of India ordinarily been born or became a resident of five in India .
Domicile by birth or residence as a person can be changed .
In fact अधिवास citizenship is denoted by domicile and not vice - versa.
The latter is distinguishable from citizenship because it is vitally related to the territory and not membership of the community which is at the root of the concept of citizenship ( Abdul Rahman v. State of Bombay AIR 1964 अधिवास .
It provides a single citizenship and is concerned with the domicile in the territory of the whole of India and not in any part of it .
There is no separate state citizenship like the United States of America .
The domicile which he has is only one domicile namely domicile in the territory of India .
( Pradeep Jain v. Union of India AIR 1984 SC 654 प्रदीप )
persons migrating from Pakistan Article 6 provides for citizenship rights of migrants from Pakistan before the commencement of the Constitution .
There are two types of distinctions among such migrants - LRB - as on July 19 1948 - RRB - when the permit system for migration was introduced in India before the प्रवास and those who came after that date .
A person who had migrated from Pakistan before July 19 1948 and would be deemed as a citizen of India at the start of the Constitution subject to birth of one of his parents or a person born in India or as a rule in India .
Thus article 8 takes care of the future citizenship needs of all Indians residing abroad .
Voluntary acquisition of citizenship of another country Article 9 provides that if a person has voluntarily acquired the citizenship of a foreign State he shall forfeit the right of citizenship of India .
This was applicable to cases arising before the commencement of the Constitution but in cases arising after the commencement of the Constitution the cases arising out of such cases shall be dealt with in accordance with the provisions of the Citizenship Act 1955 1955 .
The Supreme Court has held that it is the duty of the Government of India to determine whether or not a person has been deprived of the citizenship of India on acquisition of another country and after that no State Government is treated overseas .

Article 10 lays down that every person who is a citizen of India subject to the provisions made in Article 5 to 10 shall be a citizen of India subject to the provisions of such laws as Parliament shall exercise .
In other words it means that a citizen ' s right of citizenship cannot be छीना in any other manner than parliamentary legislation .
( Ibrahim Wazir v. State of Bombay AIR 1954 SC 229 ) .
Article 5 and the term ' used in the UK have been interpreted to cover all persons who may be in jail during trial or who may be undergoing imprisonment .
- LRB - State of Maharashtra v. Prabhakar AIR 1966 SC 1966 Sunil बत्रा v . Delhi Administration AIR 1978 SC 1978 .

Parliament ' s power to regulate right of Citizenship by law and the Citizenship Act 1955 Article 11 endows Parliament with unfettered powers for enacting legislation pertaining to the acquisition and termination of the citizenship of India and all matters connected with it .
Parliament accordingly passed the Citizenship Act नागरिकता 1955 providing for the acquisition and termination of citizenship .
Thus all matters relating to the citizenship rights after the commencement of the Constitution are to be dealt with in accordance with its provisions .
The Act was amended in 1986 to tackle the situation created by the large - scale unlawful immigration into India of the people from Bangladesh बांग्लादेश Sri Lanka and some African countries .
The amendment made the acquisition of Indian citizenship more difficult .
The equality of opportunity in public planning such as the birth clause ( 1 ) of Article 16 and ( 2 ) of all citizens of India under the State shall be granted or granted equality of opportunity in matters relating to employment or appointment to any person under the state .
But in the subsequent clause ( 3 ) ) ( 4 ) ) ( 4 ) and ( 5 ) there are four exceptional situations which can be broken by a general rule of equality of opportunity .
By virtue of this right Parliament passed the Public Employment Requirements Act 1957 . .

The Government of India Act 1919 1919 : By the 1919 सुधान Act and the rules framed there were several important changes in the Indian constitutional system .
The first Council constituted a total of 60 members of whom 34 were elected ( 20 ) nominated members and 6 nominated non - official members .
The strength of the Legislative Assembly under the Act was fixed at 140 : there were 100 elected members 26 nominated officials and the rest nominated non - official members .
As per the statutory rules the total number could be increased and there was a change in the proportion between the members of different classes of persons - so that at least 5 / 7 members of the total number are elected and less than one in the rest .
The first Legislative Assembly constituted under the 1919 Act came into existence in 1921 .
In the case of the Council of States the qualifications for property held such high that the House was reduced to the size of its wealthy members and traders alone .
In 1920 the total electorate to the Council was only 17 644 and for the Assembly seat .
The general duration of the Council was five years and that of the Assembly for three years .
The Governor - General could dissolve either House before the expiration of its full term .
It could also extend their normal life - time in special conditions .
The two Houses had equal powers but only the Assembly could grant or withhold supply.

The Government of India Act 1935 1935 aims at providing a federal structure .
It provided that in the discharge of the functions of the Governor - General he shall be required to assist and extend his functions to the Council of Ministers except where he is required to exercise his discretion or to his personal views " .
The Federal Legislature There was no reference to individual or collective responsibility of ministers in the Act though every minister was expected to be a member of either House of the Legislature .
He could preside over meetings of the Council of Ministers at his discretion .
The Federal Legislature was to consist of His Majesty represented by the Governor - General and two Chambers to be respectively known as the Council of State ( the Upper Chamber ) and the House of Assembly ( Lower Chamber ) .
The Council of State would be a permanent body not subject to dissolution but one - third of its members retire every third year .
Every Federal Assembly would operate for five years if it was not dissolved by the Governor - General in his discretion .
Each House would elect its Chairman and Deputy Chairman and would have the power to regulate subject to the provisions of the ESI Act .
The Governor - General in his discretion has the power to invite and prorogue the Legislature and to dissolve the Lower House .
No Bill would become law unless agreed to by the two Houses and assented to by the Governor - General or the Bill reserved for the purpose of His Majesty ' s Address .
Even an Act assented to by the Governor - General could be disallowed by His Majesty .
The Governor - General could remit a Bill to the Houses for reconsideration .
In the case of disagreement between the Houses the Governor - General could summon a joint meeting where the decisions could be reached by a majority the two Houses were shared nearly equal powers ; सदनों the सदनों वित्तीय - सदनों financial sector .
Money Bills could be introduced only in the lower house but the Upper House had the power to amend or reject them in the same way as the Lower House ( सदन ) and the Governor - General was empowered to resolve the difference .

The people need an organisation and they need a medium to express and utilise their sovereignty .
Under the scheme of our Constitution and its provision of universal adult franchise the people exercise their sovereign power while casting their votes to elect representatives to the Union Parliament .
The Parliament becomes the people ' s institution par excellence through which the sovereign will of the people finds expression .
Initially the Indo - Greek City States and in India during the Vedic period the people themselves assembled together to decide the matters of governance .
People thus exercised their power directly in deciding matters of the State and this kind of polity could be called direct democracy .
But with the gradual increase in the size and population of the political economy and ultimately with the formation of modern nation - states it was impossible for the people to assemble at a place to discuss matters of State and arrive at decisions smoothly.
That is why all forms of direct democracy have soon vanished from the world except in some Swiss लोकतंत्र where issues could still be decided by the people directly on matters .
Modern democracy has of necessity to be a representative democracy where people exercise their sovereignty through their elected representatives .
The term " Parliamentary " has a specially democratic polity wherein the supreme power vests in the body of people ' s representatives called Parliament .
It is the pivot which is the foundation of the political system of the country .
The President of the Republic is directly elected by an electoral college consisting of the elected members of both the Houses of Parliament and the elected members of the Legislative Assemblies of the States .
Though the President of India is a constituent of Parliament he does not sit or participate in the discussions in either of the two Houses .
There are certain constitutional functions connected with Parliament which it is required to perform and the President invites both Houses of Parliament from time to time .
He can prorogue the two Houses of Parliament and dissolve the Lok Sabha .
This is not to say that when the two Houses of Parliament are not in session and the President is satisfied that there exist conditions which required him to act immediately he may promulgated an Ordinance which was passed in his power and effect .
Further he has the power to decide after obtaining the opinion of the Election Commission whether any member duly elected is affected by ग्रस्त . in Article 108 of the Constitution .
His decision on this matter is final .
Rajya Sabha ( Rajya Sabha ) as its name indicates is Council of States or Council of States .
The different States of the Union have not been given equal representation in the Rajya Sabha .

The populations in some of the Union territories such as Andaman and Nicobar Islands Chandigarh Dadra and Nagar Haveli Daman and Diu and Lakshadweep are too small to be represented in the Rajya Sabha .
Under the Constitution the Rajya Sabha consists of not more than 250 members .

The Government of India Act of 1935 ( 1935 ) the most remarkable feature of the Government of India Act 1935 was that it envisaged an all - India federation of States formed to join the British provinces and the Union .
By the 1930 Round Table Conference India was a completely unitary state and whatever powers the Provinces had were given to them by the Centre .
The 1935 Act for the first time provided for a federal system which would consist of not only the Governors of India but also the Chief रियासतें province and the princely states .
It finally abolished the concept of a unitary system under which the British had so far been administered .
The principle of the constitution of 1919 was decentralisation rather than association .
Provinces were free from Central control in the normal circumstances .
The Act separated Burma from India and two new provinces of Orissa and Sind were created .
Keeping in view the proposed scheme at the Centre the eleven provinces of the Governors were completely मुक्त from the सरकार Central Government and the Secretary of State except for certain specific purposes .
In other words the कर Provinces were invested with a separate legal personality .
Moreover Parliament is empowered to abolish or create a Legislative Council in a State by a simple procedure not involving an amendment of the Constitution .
This can happen only by an Act of Parliament if the Legislative Assembly of a State passes a resolution to that effect by a special majority .
Last but not the least the Parliament exercises its control over the States through the Governor .
As we know the President is a constituent of the Parliament and at the same time the Executive head of the Union .
Governors of states are appointed by him and he holds office during the pleasure of the President .
Further the President may make such provisions as he thinks fit for the discharge of the functions of the Governor of the State in any contingency not provided for in the Constitution .
All these facts however do not mean that the States should be merely administrative agents of the Union in India .
No one is subject to the other in his field .
In the words of Dr . the States are as sovereign in the field set up by the Constitution as the Centre is in the sphere assigned to it by the Constitution .
The scheme of provincial autonomy envisaged by the Act provided for a executive and a legislature in every province .
The Council of Ministers was made responsible to the Legislature and could remove it by passing a vote of no - confidence .
The Legislature could exercise some control over the administration through Questions and विधानमंडल .
The Dominion Legislature could not however accept or reject nearly 80 per cent of the grant - in - aid .
In the legislative sphere the legislature could also pass laws on subjects included in the Concurrent List though in case of divergence the Federal law would prevail .

In 1973 in the राज्य नाथ Bharti v. State of Kerala 21 Supreme Court reviewed the decision in Golak Nath .
Ten of the 13 judges held that Article 368 itself contained the power to amend the Constitution and that in Article 13 ( 2 ) the law ( 2 ) did not intend to make a constitutional amendment under article 368 .
The law declared in Golak Nath ' s case was accordingly repealed .

While considering or not प्रस्तावों the various proposals received the Speaker keeps his primary duty in mind as to enable him to act in such a manner as to enable the House to consider matters originating from time to time.
Whenever the Speaker is in doubt he usually gives an opportunity to the House to express his views .
He does not so conceive his duties or interpret his powers as to act independently of the House or to override its authority or to nullify its decisions.
He is a part of the House and enjoys the powers from the House for the better functioning of the House .
He is in the ultimate analysis a servant of the House and not its master .

The Secretary - General the third important officer of the House is the Secretary - General
He is the adviser to the Speaker to the House and to the members on all parliamentary functions and activities and all matters of procedure and practice .
As a permanent officer who is the head of the Table and continues to work as a link between the changing different chambers and the सदनों General Secretary is the custodian of parliamentary conventions and traditions and is the custodian of the first houses and the experience of his own.
The Secretary - General discharges in his own right many legislative functions administrative and executive functions and provides services and facilities to the members .
He is the overall incharge of the Watch and Ward Organisation and the security in the precincts of the Parliament Estate .
The Parliament Library also functions under him. Research Reference Documentation and Information Services .
He is responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the buildings and properties of the Parliament .
As the overall head of the parliamentary Museum and Archives he is the custodian of the heritage of Parliament and the keeper of all parliamentary records .
He is the head of the legislative services and the Secretariat of the House and is responsible for its administration for maintaining discipline and for seeing that the secretarial work of the House and its Committees is organised properly and conducted efficiently and efficiently .
He provides secretarial assistance and staff to all the Parliamentary Committees and is available to them for advice.
His role for the members and committees is that of a friend philosopher and guide .
Members of various political parties approach him for advice.
To a great extent he has to maintain the same role of impartiality and objectivity as that observed by the Speaker .
He must be a fully conscious and quick - जागरूक person .
For a person holding the post of Secretary - General it is necessary that he is a genius and versatile in the manifold functions of the Parliament and is entrusted to him with a more technical and complicated nature of all kinds of officials and scholars .
The work is organised in such a manner that each unit is concerned with a particular subject or aspect of parliamentary life and is equipped with men of calibre who are equipped technically and who discharge their duties efficiently.
It is the duty of the Secretary - General to see that adequate personnel should be trained to fill the gaps occurring from time to time and that the efficiency of parliamentary work is maintained at a high level .
Much therefore depends upon the personality and mind of the occupant of the post of Secretary - General in giving shape and character to the Secretariat of the House .
He is absolutely non - partisan and objective in his approach and approach .
He is elected from among the officers who have made their mark in the service of Parliament acting in various capacities in the Secretariat of the House .
The Speaker is the authority to choose and appoint him .
Once appointed he attains the age of निवृत्ति which is 60 years at the time of retirement and continues to remain in his office till he attains that hour .
He cannot be criticised in the House and his actions in the House or outside are not discussed .
It is only responsible to the Speaker for the protection of service and freedom of the services and provision of adequate safeguards in order to ensure that he performs his duties in a most humane and just fair manner .
The Lok Sabha Secretariat is altogether separate and under the control of the Speaker so that the Parliament can get independent advice and its directions can be implemented without any outside interference or internal pressure .
The Secretary - General releases the reports and papers of the House to which he is presented by the Speaker to the members concerned ; the papers carry out the notices and the correspondence thereof to be submitted to the House ;
संसदीय as a Parliamentary Study and Training Centre he organizes new members of Parliament and State Legislature प्रशासनिक of the Indian Administrative Service विदेश Indian Foreign Services and Training and Programmes for Senior Courses अधिकारियों of Indian Universities and other Indian Services.
He accompanies parliamentary delegations abroad and attends to numerous other activities of the Parliament .
When the Commonwealth राष्ट्रमंडल Conference is held in the country the Secretary - General of the Lok Sabha is the ex - officio Secretary - General of the Conference .

Mountbatten : In March 1947 Lord Louis Mount - batten was sent as the new Viceroy to arrange for a smooth transfer of power .
He arrived in India on 22 March 1939 .
He soon came to the conclusion that for the Congress and the Muslim League there would be neither possible for them to work together in the Interim Government nor in the Constituent Assembly and that therefore communal violence was at once more disastrous .
It was already becoming clear that the partition of the country could not be avoided and that it was the only alternative to avoid extreme chaos anarchy and civil war .
Mountbatten prepared a plan for partition and after consultations with the leaders of the opposition parties in Britain a new policy statement embodying the Mountbatten Plan was issued on 3 June 1947 .

In such a case leave of the House is not necessary to pass the Bill .

( ii ) The second reading of a Bill is the most elaborate and important stage since it is precisely checked .
The second reading or the consideration stage consists of two steps which may be called the first stage and the second stage .
First stage of the first stage there is a general discussion on the whole Bill : i . e . the विधेयक i . e . the विधेयक theory of the Bill and its details .
At this stage it is open to the House to refer the Bill to the Select Committee of the House or the Joint Committee of the two Houses or to circulate it to elicit opinion thereon or straightaway take it into account .
To specify a committee the Bill may be referred to a Select Committee or a Joint Committee .
The members of the Select Committee are drawn from among the members of the House where the Bill has been introduced .
In the case of a Joint Committee the members of both the Houses are represented ; in such a case the ratio between the members of the Rajya Sabha and the Rajya Sabha is 2 .
The Chairman of the Joint Committee is appointed by the Presiding Officer of the House where the Bill has been introduced .
The Bill again passes through the Committee stage and the Bill is presented as a समिति report to the House .
After the report of a Select or a Joint Committee on the Bill has been presented to the House the Minister may move any of these three . i . e . if the Bill is returned to the notice of the Bill as agreed to the Bill again or to the Committee for the Bill later submitted to the Bill (
The controversy then is confined to the Bill as reported by the Committee and the principles of the Bill cannot be discussed again since the motion for reference to the Bill is adopted the House commits itself on the principle of the Bill .
The second stage : After the motion for consideration of the Bill or the Bill as reported by the Select / Joint Committee is adopted the वार Bill is taken up for consideration .
Each clause is placed before the House separately for discussion .
Immediately after a clause is placed before the House amendments thereto can be moved subject to the conditions of admissibility .
Division wise views are generally long and difficult as each clause is generally discussed separately and there are separate or rejected by the mover for every amendment which is also rejected by the House .
Amendments if accepted become a part of the Bill .
In the remaining cases the stages of the Bill are the same as in the case of Government Bills .

As in the case of Joint Committees the Joint Committee of the Lok Sabha consists of the Committee on Public Accounts सरकारी the Committee on Public Undertakings and the Welfare of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes and members of the Committee on Government सरकारी from the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha .
As far as possible different parties and groups are represented in Parliamentary Committees .
Usually the Committees are reconstituted every year on the basis of names of members suggested by leaders of parties / groups for consideration of and selection by the Presiding Officers .
Terms of Committees A Parliamentary Committee holds office for a period not exceeding one year or for a period specified by the Speaker or until a new Committee is मनोनीत
The Business Advisory Committee . Committee . Committee . Privileges Committee and the Rules Committee continue in office till re - constituted whereas other Standing Committees hold office for a period not exceeding one year .
If the minutes of an ad hoc Committee are not prescribed by the Speaker / Chairman the Committee continues to hold office till the completion of work and reports if so on .
The Committees have their meetings in the Parliament House or Parliament House Annexe but in special cases the meetings of the Speaker / Chairman may be held outside the limits permitted .
The Committee has the power to take oral or written evidence .
The committee may call the person for evidence to ask for the document and record but if any question arises as to whether a person or any document is referred to or not is justified to the purposes of the Committee .
The Committee may also appoint a Chief Committee to examine the matters referred to them .
A report of the उपसमिति is submitted to the main committee .
There is no public hearing .
The proceedings in Committees are largely conducted in the same manner as in the House but in a more informal atmosphere and on a non - partisan basis .
During discussion in the Committee a member can speak more than once on a question under consideration .
All questions are determined by a majority of votes of the members present and voting .
In case of an equal division of votes on a matter the Chairman has a second or casting vote .
The Committee drafts a report thereafter on the basis of the कार्यवाही of the sittings of the Committee containing the substance of deliberations of the Committee together with the recommendations made .
They can frame their own internal Rules of Procedure subject to the approval of the Speaker .
They normally do not go into questions of policy in pursuance of the fact that policy formulation is the exclusive privilege of the Parliament and a Committee is not supposed to sit in judgement on a policy already approved by Parliament .
In order to avoid possible interference in day - to - day administration the Committees examine only those acts which have already been done or not done which otherwise may have been done.
But because of the constitution and authority of the Committees no minister or official can expect them .
The Estimates Committee consists of 30 members from Lok Sabha .
Unlike the Public Accounts Committee and the Committee on Public Undertakings the members of the Rajya Sabha are not associated with it .
This committee works as a मितव्ययता economy committee and its criticisms and suggestions act as a deterrent on extravagance .

The Parliament of India exchanges delegations goodwill missions etc with foreign Parliaments and regularly participates through the Indian Parliamentary Group in the Conferences held under the auspices of the Inter - Parliamentary Union and the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association .
The Inter - Parliamentary Union is the Union of Parliamentary Group formed at National Parliaments which aims to promote their personal contacts with the members of all Parliaments and to unite them for a common action for the purpose of establishing parliamentary institutions and for their development .
The Union meets in Conference twice a year and member countries are the hosts .
The Commonwealth Parliamentary Association is an association of Commonwealth Parliamentarians with the aim of encouraging understanding and cooperation between them and to promote the study of and respect for parliamentary organisations .
The Association meets in Conference annually and also assists in holding Seminars on Parliamentary Practice and Procedure at regional levels .

Citizenship In keeping with their aim of building an integrated Indian fraternity and a united nation the founding fathers provided for one single citizenship despite a federal structure .
Unlike the United States of America there is no separate citizenship for the Union and the States and all citizens across the country have been empowered with no discrimination : , only Kashmir non - tribal areas where some special protection has been granted .
The 42nd Amendment to the Constitution inter alia added a new Part to the Constitution under the title Fundamental Duties .
In fact no rights can be viable without corresponding duties and rights of citizens without respect to the political obligations of the citizens to the State have no meaning .
An independent Judiciary has been provided in the Constitution of India .
The High Court and the Supreme Court form a single integrated judicial structure with jurisdiction over all laws - LRB - Union - RRB - State Civil Criminal or constitutional laws .
Unlike the United States of America our country does not have separate federal and State court systems .
It is not only the अभिरक्षक of individual rights and freedoms but it can be expected to interpret the Constitution from time to time and ascertain the validity of any legislation in the context of the Constitution .
The judgement of the Supreme Court is the supreme law of the country .

The Constitution of India is one of the most comprehensive documents .
It is unique in many respects .
It cannot be fitted in any particular mould pattern or model .
It is a blend of the rigid and the flexible federal and unitary and presidential and parliamentary forms .
It attempts to balance the fundamental rights of the individual on the one hand and the socio - economic interests of the people and the security of the State on the other .
Moreover it presents a via media between the principles of parliamentary sovereignty and judicial supremacy.

In the context of these developments the Drafting Committee decided to call India a Union although its Constitution might be federal .

Under the Act it was also expected that the Legislatures which had the effect on some important matters could be introduced in any House of India with the full approval of the Governor - General .
In addition to his existing power of विधानमंडल a Bill passed by the Legislature or to ascertain the wishes of His Majesty the Governor - General was empowered to enact legislations which would consider necessary to the good of British India or any part of British India .
In case of Emergency the Governor - General ' s power to promulgate Ordinances for peace and good governance of British India .
Similarly in financial matters also where the legislature was empowered to recognise or refuse to accept a grant - in - aid only and may require it from the Governor - General .
Thus the Indian Legislature under the 1919 Act was a quasi - judicial body and the administrative machinery was powerless before the Executive in all spheres of governmental activities in legislative and financial matters .
However in addition to the constitution of the Dominion Legislature the task of making international legislation was not in the hands of the Governor - General ' s Council .
The body had now to function as a cabinet and submit fiscal and legislative proposals of the government to the Legislature presided over by non - official अधिकारी .
There was a great increase in the legislative activity and several legislations which gave permanent benefit to the country were enacted .
Except for certain reserved heads of expenditure the rest of the budget had to be accepted and the government had to face great difficulties in case of the refusal of supplies and services by the House or rejection of the entire Budget .

Lok Sabha : The other House ( Lok Sabha ) is the House of the People ) .
It is directly elected by the people .
Every citizen of India - LRB - not of 18 years of age - RRB - shall be entitled to vote in the elections to the Lok Sabha - LRB - unless he is otherwise disqualified under law .
The Constitution declares that not more than one member shall be elected directly from the territorial constituencies in the States and not more than 20 members shall represent the Union territories which shall be elected in such a manner as Parliament may by law provide .
In addition the President may nominate not more than two members to represent the Anglo - Indian community .

If the Executive has almost unlimited power to formulate legislative and financial proposals and place them before the Parliament itself and to execute the accepted policies which are without some hindrance the Parliament has unlimited power to exercise information and it is impossible for the Executive .
The Executive and the administration are responsible to the Parliament .
The function of Parliament is to exercise political and financial control over the Executive and to ensure parliamentary surveillance of administration .
Parliament has the power to make laws regulating the constitution organisation the constitution agency the jurisdiction and the powers of the Courts .
The Constitution laid down that the number of judges other than the Chief Justice would not exceed seven .
Parliament was however empowered to prescribe a large number of judges by law .
Under this provision Parliament passed the Supreme Court ( Number of Judges ) Act in which the number of other judges was increased to ten and was subsequently reduced to 25 by several amendments to the Act .
Thus at present the number of judges of the Supreme Court including the Chief Justice is 26 .
Each state has a High Court which consists of the Chief Justice and such other judges as the President may deem necessary to appoint from time to time .
There are many authorities who very legitimately interpret the Constitution almost daily during the discharge of their functions .
The basic function of the Courts is to adjudicate disputes between individuals between individuals and the States between the Union and the State and between the States and while so adjudicating the Courts may be required to interpret the provisions of the Constitution and the laws .
And the interpretation given by the Supreme Court becomes the law honoured by all the courts of law .
There is no appeal against the judgement of the Supreme Court .
It remains the law of the land unless its interpretation is reviewed or reversed by the Supreme Court itself or the law or the Constitution is suitably amended by Parliament .
If an Act of Parliament is set aside by the Judiciary the Parliament can re - enact it after removing the defects for which it was set aside .
The Parliament of India is not as supreme as the British Parliament where no judicial review of legislation is permitted.
At the same time Judiciary in India is not as supreme as in the United States of America which recognises virtually no limit on the scope of judicial review .
The Parliament of India representing as it does all constitutionally organised shades of public opinion at the national level occupies a very important position in the political system of the country .
It embodies and प्रभुसत्ता the " sovereignty of the people ; it is the voice and mirror of the nation .
Members of Parliament as elected representatives of the people ventilate the people ' s grievances and opinions on various issues scrutinise the functioning of the government and make laws .
The Parliament functions as the राष्ट्र and watchdog of the nation .

The Parliament gets information from a variety of sources : but the government is the biggest source of information therefore it has to rely very much on the government departments for its information needs .
Parliament ' s right to be informed is unlimited - LRB - except that if the information given is likely to prejudice vital national interest or the security of the State it may not be insisted upon.
As far as the activities of the Government are concerned it is the duty of the Government itself to make available to Parliament the correct and clear information available from time to time .
This information is made available by the ministers making statements on the floor of the House laying reports and papers on the Table of the House or placing documents in the Parliament Library .
All these above information is important then published immediately and can be used to raise discussions in the House .

Instead of fighting to annihilate each other the parties tend to agree to disagree and to accommodate or tolerate each other .
In performing this conflict resolution role the parliamentary institution acts as a great national integrator and mediator in change.

It creates feelings of national unity which cannot be produced elsewhere .

President 's Address After the newly elected members have taken oath / affirmation and the Speaker has been elected the President addresses both Houses of Parliament assembled together in the Central Hall of the Parliament House.
The President also addresses the Houses together at the commencement of the first session of each year .
The President arrives in the State Coach at the Parliament House where he is received at the gate by the Chairman Rajya Sabha - LRB - Speaker - RRB - the Prime Minister the Minister the Minister of Parliamentary Affairs and the Secretaries - General of the two Houses .
He is then taken in a ceremonial procession to the high - domed Central Hall of Parliament along a red - कालीन route .
After the National Anthem has been played the President reads the address .
The address consists of details of policies and programmes which the government proposes to pursue in the following year .
Being a statement of the policy of the government the Address is drafted by the government .
Half - an - hour after the President ' s Address both the Houses meet in their Chamber where the copies of the President ' s Address are laid on the Table of the House by the Secretary - General .
The President ' s Address is discussed in both the Houses on a Motion of Thanks proposed by a member of the House and seconded by another member .

Within the House and in all matters connected with the House his word is final.
Independence and impartiality are the two important attributes of the office of the Speaker .
He ranks higher than all the ministers except the prime minister .
His salary and allowances are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India - which is they do not have to be voted by Parliament .
His conduct cannot be discussed except on a substantive motion .
He shall not vote in the House except when there is an equality of votes.
Two and when he gives his casting vote in such a case of equality it is always in accordance with well - established parliamentary principles and practices .
Upon his election as Speaker he अलग himself from all the activities of his party .
He does not hold any party office but does not participate in any party meetings or activities and is far away from political controversies and party campaigns .
He performs these functions in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution and the Rules of Procedure and Conduct of Business in the Lok Sabha .
His decision in all parliamentary matters is final .
The Speaker has residuary powers to give directions in respect of matters not specifically provided in the Rules .
While doing so he may ask a member or the government to provide such facts evidence and information as may be necessary to arrive at a decision .
The Speaker has many powers to govern the business of the House in a peaceful and orderly manner .
He can order any member to discontinue his speech or to withdraw words or expressions which he feels are या or अभद्र .
He may order that anything said by a member without his permission shall not be included in the proceedings and that anything found / found is excluded from the course of action .
The words or extracts of the speeches ordered to be left out of record as they are of the nature of words or speeches as they are made cannot be published by the Press as the rights of other persons .
The Speaker may ask any member for a day or for any part of the day to retire from the House or to suspend an appropriate motion when there is a breach of disorder .
It is the duty of the Speaker to exercise discipline among all the members and to give them due respect and acceptance of their decisions and decision .
Whenever he speaks in the middle or rises to propose or raise questions for the purpose of raising a question he makes some remarks or gives his rulings he must be heard in silence .
The Speaker also determines whether there is a prima facie case for a matter relating to a breach of privilege or contempt of the House , or the conduct of a member being conducted to a Committee for investigation.
If he does not give his consent the matter is not dealt further .
The statements contained in the House to protect the dignity of persons and to prevent any member from making such a statement if he has not given the evidence or the evidence before him .
The Speaker has to be sensitive to the atmosphere in the House .
He communicates the decisions of the House to the authorities concerned and requires them to comply with the terms of such decisions .
All the Parliamentary Committees of the Lok Sabha are constituted by him or by the House .
They function under his control and direction.
The Business Advisory Committee . - LRB - generally Purposes Committee and the Rules Committee work directly under his Chairmanship .
It determines what matters are financial matters which fall within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Lok Sabha .

No - confidence Motion The Council of Ministers remains in office till the confidence of the Lok Sabha is secured .
In order to ascertain this confidence a motion in the said rules exist which is called a no - confidence motion .

This responsibility is सामूहित .

( a ) Budget is presented in two parts of our Parliament - the budget is presented in respect of railway finance i . e . the railway budget and the general budget .
The primary idea behind presenting a separate budget for the railways is to secure stability for civil estimates by providing for an assured contribution by the railways and also to introduce flexibility in the administration of railway finance .
The Railway Budget is presented to the Lok Sabha by the Minister of Railways every year in the third week of February and the General Budget is presented by the Finance Minister on the last working day of February at फरवरी .
The Budget is presented with a Budget Speech which is in fact one of the most important speeches in Parliament .
This speech is made in two parts : " A " general economic survey of the country " and Part B contains the taxation proposals for the ensuing financial year .
A copy of the Budget is laid on the Table of the Rajya Sabha after the speech of the Finance Minister in the Lok Sabha .
Immediately thereafter the minister introduces a Bill which consists of the taxation proposals of the government .
( a ) Discussion on the budget is essentially a body for consultation .
The passage of the Budget is marked by deep and thorough discussions in both the Houses of Parliament .
Discussion on the Budget starts after a few days of its presentation .
This gives members the time required for fully studying the text of the Budget and to discuss financial proposals among themselves .
Budget is discussed in two stages : i General discussion " and then in detail the demands for grants and voting .
Besides opportunity for discussion on various financial proposals arises during consideration and passing of Appropriation Bill and the Finance Bill .
( iii ) General discussion on the Budget starts with a general debate which runs in both the Houses of Parliament for three or four days .
First at this stage members deal with the general aspects of fiscal and economic policies of the government and do not go into details of taxation and expenditure .
The general debate thus offers an occasion for each House to express its views .
The government may also get an idea as to how a particular proposal will take place in the subsequent stages .
It may be noted that in accordance with the power conferred by the Rajya Sabha it is not concerned with the Budget beyond general discussion .
( 2 ) Discussion on Demands for Grants and in accordance with the procedure the discussion and the voting of demands for grants in another .
Generally separate demands are made for the grants proposed for each ministry .
The demands are related to the expenditure part of the Budget and are in the nature of request made by the Executive to the Lok Sabha for grant of authority to spend the amount asked .
Demands are required to be made in the form of a motion but in practice they are assumed to have been moved ; and are proposed by the Chair to save the time of the House .
During the discussion on demands which is lively the policy and the working of the ministry comes in for close scrutiny.
Time is allotted for each ministry to discuss demands .
Members can disapprove of the policies of the Ministry or suggest measures for economy in the administration or to focus attention of the ministry for specific local grievances .
The members can do so by moving a subsidiary motion to the main motion for demands for grants .
These subsidiary motions are called in parliamentary parlance Cut motion .
The Business Advisory Committee fixes a time limit for voting a particular demand and for all the demands for grants including the Budget .
As soon as the time limit for any demand is over the discussion process of के is applied and the demand is put to vote .
Likewise on the last day allotted for all the demands not disposed of so far as they are put to vote - whether they have been discussed or not .
This process is known as गिलोटिन .
Also the discussion on demands for grants ceases .
Perusal of the Standing Committees concerned with the द्वारा revealed that every year before the गिलोटिन came to be known as ' a ' handful ' was at one time only a संसदीय of two or three ' ministries ' demands for grants to the House and the government '
Seventeen Standing Committees of the Departments belonging to the Departments have been entrusted with the task of considering the Demands for Grants of related ministries and departments and reporting to the House before voting on demand .
After the 1994 - 95 demands were presented to the Parliament both the Houses were adjourned for a period of one month to enable the respective Standing Committees to examine them and discuss them .
During the 1994 Budget Session these committees presented 48 reports on demands for grants for 1994 - 95 .
( c ) The Appropriation Bill ( Under the Constitution ) No money from the Consolidated Fund of India can be withdrawn without laws by Parliament .
This Bill means to give statutory rights to the government for व्यय expenditure from the Consolidated Fund as its name is obvious .
The procedure for considering and passing of an Appropriation Bill is the same as in the case of any other Bill ; except that the debate is confined to such cases where the demands cannot be raised and raised during the debate .
After the Bill has been passed by the Lok Sabha the Speaker certifies it as a Money Bill and is passed to the Rajya Sabha .
The Rajya Sabha has no power to amend or reject the Bill and has to give its consent to the Bill .
The Bill thereafter is presented to the President for his assent .
( d ) Financial proposals of the government for the coming year are included in a Bill called the Finance Bill which is ordinarily introduced in the Lok Sabha after the budget is presented every year .
Discussion on a Bill covers matters relating to general administration and local grievances within the sphere of the Union Government .
While general criticism of the policy of the government is permitted discussion on the details of particular estimates cannot be discussed .
In short the whole administration comes under review but questions which have already been discussed cannot be discussed again .
This Bill has to be considered and passed by the Parliament within 75 days after it has been introduced and assented to by the President .
Vote on Account In a democratic set - up the government endeavours to give full opportunity to Parliament to discuss the budgetary provisions and the tax proposals .
The passage of the Budget carries on from its presentation to discussion and voting of demands for grants and adopting Appropriation and Finance Bills generally after the start of the current financial year .
So long as the demands are not met by Parliament it is necessary that the government should have enough money to carry out the administration of the country .
So there is a special provision for vote on account which empowers the Lok Sabha to make a grant in advance for a part of the financial year until the completion of the budgetary procedure .
During an election year the vote on account may be taken for a longer period say three or four months if it is anticipated that the main demands and the Appropriation Bill will take longer than two months to be passed by the House .
As a convention vote on account is considered a formal matter and passed by the Lok Sabha without any discussion .
Vote on account is passed when a general discussion on the Budget is over and a discussion on demands for grants is taken up .
In the case of the Railway Budget which is passed before 31 March no vote on account is taken but if necessary it may be held in the election year .
Supplementary and Excess Demands for Grants No expenditure can be incurred by the Parliament without its sanction .
If the amount awarded for a particular service is found insufficient for the purpose of that year or on any new service which is not envisaged in the budget of that year the President shall give rise to the additional demand i . e .
If
All cases of such excesses are brought to the notice of the Parliament by the Comptroller and Auditor General on the Appropriation Account .
The excesses are then examined by the Public Accounts Committee which makes recommendations on the regularisation of its report to the House .
Supplementary Demands for Grants are made to the House before the end of the financial year and the demands are made ; while the demands for excess grants are actually met after the expenditure has been actually spent and the same is presented after the financial year has been over .
Legislative Procedure Regarding Ordinary Bills ( a draft of Bills ) As soon as any legislative proposal is put forth the ministry concerned begins to notice what its political commitments may be financial and other implications.
If other ministries or the state governments are also concerned they are consulted .
Professionals and various interest groups such as business labour agriculture and industry if considered necessary are also consulted.
The Bill is then examined in detail by the administrative Ministry in consultation with all the concerned authorities and is given a final shape .
After all this the Bill is ready to be brought before the House .
It can be introduced in either of the two Houses by the minister concerned .
In order to permit the introduction of the Bill the minister is required to furnish seven days notice and two copies of the Bill duly corrected are sent to the Secretary - General of the House in which the Bill is to be introduced .
After the Bill is found complete in all respects by the Secretariat it is included in the List of Business on a date selected by the Speaker or the Chairman as the case may be decided for this purpose .
Normally copies of the Bill should be made available to the members at least two days before the date on which it is proposed to be introduced .
( Two ) Three Reading - A Bill has to pass through various stages in the Parliament before it becomes an Act .
Each Bill undergoes three readings in each House ( सदन ) i . e . First Reading Second Reading and Third Reading .
( a ) First Reading it is necessary to ask the House to introduce a Bill .

But if the motion for introduction of a Bill is opposed on the ground that the proposed legislation is outside the legislative competence of the Parliament the Chair may permit a full discussion in which the Attorney General also participates .
After that the question is put to vote of the House .
Because there is no restriction on the number of Bills to be introduced in a day a minister may introduce as many Bills as he wants.
Even before introduction of a Bill can be published in the Gazette with permission of the Speaker / Chairman .

The amendments to various clauses can be moved by members of the Committee .
The Committee can also take evidence of experts associations or public bodies who are interested in the legislation .
In Committees the procedure for consideration of a Bill is the same as in the House .

Special Procedure Regarding Money Bills A Money Bill cannot be introduced in the Rajya Sabha .
It can be introduced only in the Lok Sabha on the recommendation of the President .

It is obvious that the framers of the Constitution took Parliamentary Committees for granted and left it to the Houses to make provisions for them in their Rules of Procedure .
Under the Rules of the Lok Sabha not every Committee consisting of members of Parliament is a Parliamentary Committee suo सभा .
In fact Consultative Committees do not report to anybody but merely provide a forum for informal exchange of views between the ministers and members of Parliament interested in their departments.
They are not parliamentary committees .
There are two types of parliamentary committees in India ( i . e . one ) permanent committees and two ad hoc .
The standing committees are those which are appointed by the House every year or time as the case may be by the Speaker or the Speaker / Chairman and the members of the non - official members are appointed by the Speaker or the members of the House .
Standing Committees in each House ( and certain Joint Committees ) may be categorised in terms of their functions .
Their recommendations are intended to tone up the administration for economic efficient and speedy execution of these policies and programmes .
Reports of these Committees have earned them considerable respect from all sections of the society both official and non - official .
Each recommendation is carefully analysed and processed and the administration always endeavours to remove the faults and lapses pointed out by the Committees and to act in accordance with the recommendations made by the Committees .
The Financial Committees have developed adequate procedures to ensure that the Government gives due consideration to their recommendations and the recommendations which are not accepted be conveyed to the Committees for reasons of non - acceptance .
The progress in the implementation of the recommendations as well as any unresolved differences between the Committees and the government are brought to the notice of the House by way of Action Taken Report " .
The elaborate and effective procedure for follow - up of the recommendations made by these Committees is essentially an Indian innovation to the parliamentary procedures prevalent elsewhere .
All the three Financial Committees are elected by the House for one another .
Ministers can neither become members of these Committees nor can they be asked to appear before them for the purpose of giving evidence .
Their Chairmen are nominated by the Speaker .
Committee on संसदीय In a parliamentary democracy like we have it : There is an inherent right of the people to present petitions to the Parliament with a view to व्य grievances and seeking redressal thereof and offering constructive suggestions on matters of public importance .
This right is exercised through the mechanism of a Committee on Petitions .
Each House has a Committee on Petitions .
In the Lok Sabha the Committee consists of 15 members while in the Rajya Sabha it has 10 members .
The function of the Committee on Petitions is to examine every petition which after presentation to the House stands referred to the Committee .
After taking such evidence the Committee reports to the House on specific complaints made in the petitions which he thinks fit .
The Committee suggests remedial measures either on the specific case under review or in a general way to prevent such cases in future .
The Committee also considers representations including letters and telegrams received from various individuals and associations which are not covered by the rules relating to petitions and gives directions for their proper settlement .
This Committee has already made its mark in affording parliamentary support to the common man in the matter of redressal of his just grievances .
It has proved to be a real boon to those wronged and oppressed citizens for whom no remedy or relief is available elsewhere .
In the Lok Sabha the Committee consists of 15 members while in the Rajya Sabha it has 10 members .
In order to ensure that there is an effective and continuous check on the possibility of misuse of such power by the administration each House of Parliament has its own Committee on Subordinate Legislation .
The Committee of each House consists of 15 members nominated by the Speaker / Chairman .
The , Committee is generally reconstituted every year .
The Committee examines all Bills which seek to prove whether suitable provisions have been made to lay their rules or orders on the Table of the House .
If the Committee concludes that the provision made in the Bill passed by the legislative powers should be either totally or या or amended it may report to the House before the Bill can be considered .
The Committee consists of 30 members ( 20 from Lok Sabha and 10 from Rajya Sabha elected by the respective Houses of Parliament from amongst their members .
The functions of the Committee are to consider the Report of the Commissioner for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes and report to the Parliament the measures taken or required to be undertaken by the government .
The Committee also ensures that constitutional safeguards are given effect to these backward communities .
( vi ) Service Committees There are also a few Committees of the Parliament which look into various kinds of facilities and services to the members and other matters connected with the functioning of the members of the Houses of Parliament .
These are the General Purposes Committee the Library Committee the Joint Library Committee and the Salaries and Allowances of Members of Parliament.
General Purposes Committee : Each House has a General Purposes Committee .
The Presiding Officer of the concerned House is the ex - officio Chairman of the Committee .
The Committee consists of the Deputy Speaker or Deputy Chairman as the case may be members of Panel of Chairmen Chairmen from all the Standing Committees of that House दलों of recognised parties / groups and other members nominated by the Presiding Officer .
The Committee is constituted to advise on such ad hoc matters as do not appropriately fall within the purview of any other Parliamentary Committee and which may be referred to it from time to time .
The Library Committee is a joint committee of the two Houses consisting of six members of the Lok Sabha ( including the Deputy Speaker ) nominated by the Speaker and three members of the Rajya Sabha nominated by its Chairman .
The main function of this committee is to help the members in the use of the library and its allied services . i . e . reference research and documentation services .
It advises the Speaker on matters pertaining to the selection of books framing of library rules and its future planning etc .
A Joint Committee on Salaries and Allowances of Members of Parliament was constituted to frame rules under the Salaries and Allowances of Members of Parliament Act 1954 .
It consists of 10 members from Lok Sabha and 5 from Rajya Sabha .
The functions of the Committee are to provide for the members of the two Houses for the purpose of consultation with the Government of India rules to regulate the payment of their daily and travelling allowances etc .

Customs and customs are other than the rules of parliamentary etiquette which the members have to follow in the House ; there are customs and practices which are equally important for maintaining a proper standard of parliamentary life and maintaining the dignity of the House and its members .

Federal Constitutions are usually classified as rigid .

Only in case of certain provisions in addition to a special majority of the two Houses of Parliament an amendment would require the ratification of not more than half the States Parties .

In other words it stood for a solemn commitment to religious freedom for all .
This was reinforced by the principles of equality of status and opportunity and of fraternity among all the people of India .
The vision of the founding fathers was that of a nation transcending all diversities of religion and order .
He was not opposed to religion but he hoped that it would be possible to forge political unity and that religious differences would not hamper nation building .
The Constitution envisaged a new social order free from communal conflicts and based on social democracy economic and political justice .
It visualized a polity under which laws would not discriminate between citizens on grounds of religion caste or creed .
The Constitution sought to establish a 'secular' order under which the majority of the population did not enjoy any special privileges or preferential treatment at the hands of the State and the religious rights of the minorities were protected in different ways .
It seems necessary that the term secularism be clearly defined in the Constitution itself and the existing laws are firmly implemented and even radical legislation is passed so that no party or individual can misuse religion for political purposes .
