Equality before law and Equal protection of laws Article 14 of the Constitution enunciates the fundamental right of every person not to be denied within the territory of India equal protection of law and laws .
The protection provided by this article is not limited to citizens only but is applicable to all individuals .
It embodies the principle contained in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights that all are equal before the law and are entitled to equal protection without any distinction .
In a singular in the term equality before law means the same thing as the substance of law or of law or of justice .
On the other hand in the term of ' equal protection of the laws ' in the first instance the word विधि clearly directs the legal law and the provision made by it to the State to ensure that all safeguards without any exception are provided .
But the Supreme Court has not seen any such distinction .
In fact it has been suggested by Chief Justice शास्त्री Shastri that the second term is the result of the first appointment and that it is very difficult to imagine the situation in which laws will not discriminate against equality of law .
( State of West Bengal v. Anwar AH Sarkar AIR 1952 SC 75 ) .
Laws should be applied to all in a uniform manner .
The Supreme Court has held that there is often a need for separate treatment of different kinds of people .
भारत भारत Lal v. Union of India AIR 1951 SC 41 .
If the classification is not reasonable and does not satisfy the two conditions mentioned above the impugned legislation or executive action would plainly be arbitrary and the guarantee of equality under article 14 would be violation .
Therefore wherever it is in any case that has been dealt with by a legislative or executive or by any authority under article 12 निरंकुशता of राज्य निरंकुशता Act of 1981 निरंकुशता the action of the State .
Thus the new approach introduced by the Supreme Court has widened the scope for the operation of Article 14 and no longer need for any discrimination against others .
प्राजैक्ट v प्राजैक्ट and इक्विपमेंट Corporation ( 1984 ) 3 SCC 328 .
The prohibition on the ground of discrimination on grounds of non - conventional race caste sex or place of birth where Article 14 seeks the preservation of equality and laws before the successor article 15 to 18 general principles in relation to the citizens of India .
Article 15 enjoins the state not to discriminate against any citizen only on grounds of religion caste creed sex place of birth or place of any of them .
The use of the word alone is meaningful .
Any distinctions based on one or more grounds and on other grounds or ground shall not be affected by this article ( राज्य v. State of Bombay AIR 1953 ( C ) निवास AIR 1953 ( राज्य ) or otherwise based on residence ) .
Clause 2 of the article provide for special application of the ban .
The prohibition obviously covers actions both on the part of the State and the general public .
( A . K . Gopalan v. State of Madras AIR 1950 SC 27 ) .
It is necessary that the restrictions imposed by law must be reasonable whether arbitrary or of excessive nature and the onus of proving it to the satisfaction of the court lies with the state .
The भारी the restriction the heavier the onus to prove the reasonableness ( राज्य Ahmed v. State of Uttar Pradesh AIR 1954 SC दायित्व दायित्व ) .
Since the Constitution does not define the " reasonable restrictions it has to be on the basis of its own merits .
G . Rao ( AIR 1952 SC 196 ) .
The standard is really an elastic one and varies in each case with time space and condition .
The founding fathers made it clear that they were not writing the Constitution absolutely independent or completely afresh .
They had deliberately decided not to ignore the past but to build on the existing structure and experience of the past .
The Constitution of India had an organic growth .
Category B : those Bills containing provisions involving expenditure from the Consolidated Fund ( articles 110 and 117 ) .
The special procedure for the धन is defined in Article 110 specifying that a Money Bill is a Bill which provides only to the subjects for the custody of the Consolidated Fund . of the Consolidated Fund and the custody of a Consolidated Fund .
If a question arises as to whether a Bill is a Money Bill the decision of the Speaker shall be final .
Every Money Bill when presented to the President for his assent he shall be certified by the Speaker as such a Bill ( article 110 ) .
A Money Bill can be introduced only in the Lok Sabha and only on the recommendation of the President .
After it is passed by the Lok Sabha and transmitted to the Rajya Sabha the latter may make recommendations if any within a period of 14 days and the Lok Sabha may accept or reject all or any of the recommendations of the House .
Thereafter it is deemed to have been passed by both the Houses with the amendments accepted by the Lok Sabha .

Language of Legislatures Article 120 lays down the official language of Parliament .

Parliament and State Legislatures The Constitution of India has established a federal system of governance in the country as there is a distribution of legislative executive and financial powers between the Union and the States.
But it is extremely doubtful if Indian polity can be described as Federal or फेडरल .
The word के was nowhere used in the text of the Constitution.
In fact the proposal to describe India as a फेडरशन was specifically turned down in the Constituent Assembly .
Article 1 of the Constitution described India as the Union of States .
There are many such features in the Constitution and a large number of its provisions which very clearly and strongly विरूद्ध against it being a federal Constitution .
Unlike the United States of America the citizenship in India is one and the flag is one .
The judiciary is also integrated and not divided between the Union and the states .
In short there may be a difference of opinion about whether Indian polity is federal unitary or quasi - federal or it is a political arrangement which is unitary in spirit but federal in structure .
The Union of India has 25 states now and seven Union Territories (UTs) as mentioned in the First Schedule of the Constitution .

The procedure for constitutional amendment as spelled out in the Constitution has certain distinctive features which clearly mark out the Parliament ' s constituent capacity from its ordinary role as a legislature .
First an amendment of the Constitution can be initiated only by introducing a Bill in one House of Parliament ( Parliament ) because the initiative in the matter of constitutional amendment is exclusively reserved for Parliament .
Second an exclusive majority in the provisions of the Constitution can be amended by Parliament - LRB - Parliament - RRB - ( that is by a majority of the total membership of each House and by at least two - thirds of the members present and voting .
Only in the case of the constitutional provisions of a limited category ( such as the List of Seventh Schedule ' in the Parliament provisions relating to the States ( article 368 etc ) the amendment Bill in the case of a special majority set by the Parliament is less than half .

A All - Parties Conference organised at Bombay on 19 May 1928 appointed a committee under the chairmanship of Motilal Nehru to formulate the principles of the Constitution of India .
The Report embodied not only the perspective of the contemporary nationalist ideology but also a framework of the draft constitution of India .
The draft constitution of India was based on the principle of Dominion Status.
It provided for certain fundamental rights and a federal system with maximum autonomy granted to the units but residuary powers vested in the Central Government .
Almost twenty - one years later it was incorporated in the Constitution of free India adopted by the Constituent Assembly on 26 November 1949 .
The White Paper issued after the third Round Table Conference outlined the British government ' s proposal for constitutional reforms in India .
In June 1934 the Congress Working Committee declared that the only satisfactory alternative to the White Paper was a constitution drawn up by a constituent assembly elected on the basis of adult franchise .
This was the first occasion when a formal demand for the Constituent Assembly was raised .
The Executive of the All India Congress Committee adopted a resolution at its meeting held at Patna on 5 - 7 December 1934 through which the Joint Parliamentary Committee ( 1933 - 34 ) scheme of constitutional reforms recommended that it was dropped and rejected .

Budget of the Two Houses of Parliament The position of independence is maintained even in the matter of expenditure incurred in respect of salaries and allowance of the members and officers of the Parliament .
These expenses are met from the Consolidated Fund of India .
As in the case of other ministries of the Government of India separate demands for grants in respect of the Rajya Sabha and the Lok Sabha are laid before both Houses of Parliament .
The Parliament sanctions the expenditure through the Appropriation Act every year .
No cut motions or any discussion relating to the demands of the two Houses and their Secretariats is allowed on the floor of the House .
संसदीय of hands to attract the attention of the Chair is not considered to be the normal parliamentary practice .
No member should speak unless he has caught the eye of the Chair and the Chair is asked to speak to him .
The practice of exchanging arguments by members between themselves or of indulging in a talk of another member or of the minister ' s statement has been deprecated by the Speaker .
A member addressing the House has to resume his seat when any other member has interposed in the course of the debate to raise a point of order or to offer a personal explanation with the permission of the Chair.
If a member wants to comment on a matter before the House or any other member speaking he / she is required to ask the Chair whether to seek any matter made under consideration of the House or for the purpose of any explanation .
The member should speak from his allotted place and rise .
However if a member is unable to do so he is permitted to speak while sitting by the Speaker .
A member should not address the members of the House while speaking but he should always address the Chair and speak to other members through the Chair .
This theory may appear to be a mere formality but it is strictly practised so that the debate does not take the form of dialogue between the members .
After examining the notice if the Speaker feels that there is no prima facie case for a breach of privilege or the matter to be raised is not in order he is permitted to give his consent to the Speaker concerned .

PART II नागरिकता 5 - 11 Citizenship constitutes the indispensable foundational principle of democratic polity .
Broadly the amended section 3 of the नागरिकता fundamental Act provided that citizenship by birth could be acquired by a person only when either of his parents was a citizen of India .
Moreover the Act made provisions for acquisition of Indian citizenship by birth , रजिस्ट्रीकरण रजिस्ट्रीकरण registration नागरिकता or through incorporation of the territory .
Likewise it provided for termination of citizenship by way of renunciation voluntary acquisition of citizenship of another country or through compulsory deprivation by the Government of India on certain grounds .
The Act also made specific provisions regarding Commonwealth citizenship .
Any person born outside India after 26 January 1950 subject to certain requirements will be a citizen of India ( नागरिक ) if his father was a citizen of India at the time of his birth .
It is important to remember in regard to the citizenship provisions in the Constitution and this law that the framers of the Constitution decided to provide for a single Indian citizenship with a view to building an integrated Indian nation and a united fraternity .
All citizens irrespective of their birth in any state have the same rights and duties all over the country without distinction .
PART III - 35 . : When the Constituent Assembly took over the task of framing the Constitution he first considered to be a ' right ' .
A comprehensive charter of rights was soon evolved through various stages in the Assembly and its Committees .
Dr .
Coming closely on the heels of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights India ' s Constitution मानव to the contemporary democratic and humanitarian temper and constitutional practice in other countries of the world .
It was a testimony to how eager the founding fathers were to incorporate and implement the basic principles enunciated in the Universal Declaration .
Also incorporation of a charter of fundamental rights in our Constitution became necessary in view of the special problem of minorities and the need to assure them of the fullest protection of their rights .
The values of freedom and equality befitting the dignity of man in the Preamble are eloquently proclaimed .
These fundamental rights substantially cover all the traditional civil and political rights enumerated in articles 2 to 21 of the Universal Declaration .
Equality before law and equal protection of all laws ( Article 14 ) protection of conviction for offences ( article 20 ) protection of life and personal liberty ( article 21 ) against arrest and detention .
But there are some rights which can be claimed only by the citizens such as religion caste creed sex or place of birth depending on the importance of birth ( article 15 ) नागरिकों of public employment expression ( articles 16 ) and the expression of opportunity ( Article नागरिकों .
Originally article 19 ( l ) and Article 31 contained the right to property subject to the right of compulsory acquisition for public purpose by the authority of the law of the State to acquire that property i . e . to acquire hold and sell .
But when the Constitution ( 44th Amendment ) Act 1978 1978 omitted the sub - clause ( f ) of Article 19 ( f ) and all Article 31 ) - the right to property ceased to be a fundamental right .

Ambedkar had categorically stated that the Directive Principles were not intended to be mere pious घोषणाएं .
The Directive Principles are an effective part of the Constitution and are an important part in that behalf the Constitution seeks to achieve the ideal of a democratic welfare state in the Preamble and to the realization of the social and economic revolution that the founders had dreamt of .
The Preamble the Fundamental Rights and the Directive Principles together .

It is now clear that there is no essential dichotomy between Rights and Duties or between the Fundamental Rights and the Directive Principles .
They complement and supplement each other .

In the matter of power of Parliament the Supreme Court has also given different views ( vide A . S . M . S . न्यायालय v. State of Madras AIR 1950 SC प्रभुता ) दिल्ली on Delhi laws ( राज्य ) .
It has however been held in the Gopalan case that within the specified limits of its powers the Parliament is supreme .
Functions of Parliament . Traditionally the main function of a legislature is to legislate .
Under article 245 - 246 Parliament can make laws for the whole or any part of India within its area of competence as defined and delimited under the distribution of legislative powers between the Union and the States vide the Seventh Schedule .
Only the Parliament can legislate in respect of the Union List .
Both the Union and the State Governments have concurrent power to legislate in respect of entries in the concurrent sphere .
If there is a conflict between the Union and the State laws the former prevails ( article 254 ) .
Also the residuary powers vest in the Parliament ( Article शक्तियां and the entry 97 of the Union List .
A number of articles empower Parliament to make laws in various matters by virtue of such powers as may be provided by Parliament by law otherwise than Parliament by Parliament " Parliament may by law be prescribed by Parliament by Parliament " Parliament ' and so on .
No grounds arguments proofs or justification are required .
Parliamentary control over public finance - the power to levy or modify taxes and the voting of supplies and grants - is the most important checks against the Executive assuming arbitrary powers .
No taxes can be legally levied and no expenditure incurred from the public exchequer without specific parliamentary authorization by law ( articles 114 - 116 and 265 ) .
Administrative accountability is ensured through legislation through parliamentary devices like , संसदीय discussions on various motions संसद scrutiny through the संसद Committee which in fact represents Parliament and controls its department on behalf of Parliament .
For further study see Subhash C. Kashyap Our Parliament . National Book Trust New Delhi .
Judges of the Supreme Court are to be paid such salaries as may be determined by Parliament by law and until so determined salaries as specified in the Second Schedule ( article 125 ) .
When the post of Chief Justice of India is vacant or when the Chief Justice is unable to attend the duties of his office the President shall appoint one of the other judges of the court and he shall perform the duties of the Chief Justice ( article 126 ) .
If the quorum of the judges of that court are not available at any time to hold or to hold the session of the Supreme Court he is entitled to the appointment of one of the High Court Judges considered necessary to be such High Court .
He can do so only with previous consent of the President and after consultation with the Chief Justice of the High Court concerned .
The judge so appointed is duty bound to give priority to the Supreme Court ' s duties .
The Chief Justice of India may summon and appoint a retired judge of the Supreme Court or a retired judge of the Supreme Court as he may deem necessary to appoint and act as Judge of the Supreme Court .
This also can be done with the consent of the President and of the person to be so appointed ( articles 127 and 128 ) .
Power and jurisdiction of the Supreme Court
The President may seek the opinion of the Supreme Court on any question of law or fact of public importance on which he thinks it expedient to obtain such an opinion .
After such instructions received from the President the Supreme Court may report to the President its opinion on it after a hearing as it deems fit .
The President is free to recognise him or her .
The President may also seek the agreement of a treaty प्रसंविदा covenant engagement प्रसंविदा engagement प्रसंविदा . or any other instrument which had been entered into or executed before the commencement of this Constitution and is followed by the Supreme Court .
Under article 138 the Supreme Court shall have such further jurisdiction and powers with respect to any of the matters in the Union List as Parliament may by law .
This enlarges the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court and provides it with very special jurisdiction to hear cases of most urgent nature directly and in its original jurisdiction for speedy disposal .
The due process of law gives wide scope to the Supreme Court to grant protection to the rights of its citizens .
It can declare laws violative of these rights void not only on substantive grounds of being unlawful but also on procedural grounds of being unreasonable.
It is not expected to go into the question of its reasonableness suitability or policy implications.
The Supreme Court pronounces its judgement on a specific case through a specific petition .
He does not give the opinion or advice on general instructions .
There should be an aggrieved person who petitions the Court to challenge the constitutionality of the statute which has adversely affected his rights .
He has to show that he has suffered from immediate injury as a result of the enforcement of the statute and that the damage complained of is है .
This judgement राहत individual / citizen or voluntary organisations to seek judicial relief in the interest of the general public .
Effect of the law declared against the Constitution : A law declared by Article 141 shall be binding on all courts within the territory of India .
Therefore if the Supreme Court declares a law to be opposed to the Constitution even if it is a legislative competence or a violation of the fundamental rights it shall be binding on all courts in the territory of India .
Independence of the judiciary In a representative democracy administration of justice assumes special significance in view of the rights of individuals which need protection against executive or legislative interference .
An independent and supreme judiciary is an essential requisite of a federal polity wherein there is a constitutional division of powers between the federal government and governments of its constituent units and a functional division of powers between the executive कार्यपालिका legislature and judiciary .
Also an independent and impartial judiciary is an essential requisite for ensuring human rights and protecting democracy .
Only an independent judiciary can act effectively as the guardian of the rights of the individual and of the Constitution .
The Constitution provides for a High Court for each state .
Parliament may however establish by law a common High Court for two or more States or for two or more States and a Union Territory ( articles न्यायालय and न्यायालय ) .
A higher court issues a lower court or tribunal and is intended to prohibit it from exceeding its jurisdiction .
Besides writs the High Court under Article 226 can also issue other directions and orders in the interest of justice to the people ( C . 440 v . 440 AIR 1954 SC 440 ) .
( See also under High Court For Public Interest Litigation ) the Governor appoints district judges in consultation with the High Court .
A person who is not already in Government Service should have at least seven years' experience at the bar to become eligible for the post of a district judge ( article 233 ) .
Article 20वें inserted by the twentieth Amendment Act validated the appointment of certain district judges and the judgements given by them ( articles 233 ) .
Appointment of persons other than district judges to the judicial service of a State shall be made by the Governor in accordance with rules made thereunder.
Besides the State Public Service Commission the High Court has to be consulted in the matter of such appointments ( article नियुक्तियों ) .
It may therefore be said that there are several States and states within the Constitution of India .
Generally speaking provisions for the States follow the Union - style .
Even at the State level there is a parliamentary system of government with a constitutional Head and the ministers are responsible for the popular elected House of the Legislature .
The minister uses the true executive power .
The President may at any time withdraw from his post ( the Union of India v. Union of India AIR 1982 .

executive powers vest in the Governor of the State and is exercised by him either directly or through his subordinate officers ( article अधिकारियों ) in accordance with the Constitution .
The executive power of the State is सह with its legislative power .
The Governor appoints the Advocate - General of the State the Chairman and members of the State Public Service Commission and the judges of subordinate courts ( articles 165 316 283 165 and 284 .
The Governor appoints the Chief Minister and other ministers on the advice of the Chief Minister .
In practice सभा means that only a person supported by a majority in the Assembly is to be appointed the Chief Minister and the Council holds office only till he derives the confidence of the House ( article सभा ) .
He may also nominate to the Legislative Assembly a person from the Anglo - Indian community if he feels the community needs representation and is not adequately represented in the Assembly ( articles सभा ) .
The Government of India Act 1935 1935 proposed to set up a federal polity in India with a central government and the Provinces deriving their jurisdiction and powers from the Crown .
Since a limited responsible government was established only at the provincial level the nationalists naturally asked for more powers for provincial legislatures .
When the Constituent Assembly met in 1946 and early 1947 the idea was to have a federation with a Centre having limited powers .
Before the Union Constitution Committee could transact any worthwhile business the Mountbatten Plan of 3 June 1947 was announced .
All hopes of preserving the unity of the nation vanished and the partition of the country on communal lines became a firm decision .
The Union Constitution Committee and the Provincial Constitution Committee decided at a joint meeting on 5 June that in view of the 3 June announcement the limitations imposed by the Cabinet Mission ' s plan on the form of the Constitution were lost .
Once partition had become a reality there was no need to appease the Muslim League and restrict the powers of the Union Government .
If there is an anomaly in the laws made by Parliament under article 249 and 250 laws and the laws made by the State Legislatures the laws made by Parliament will अभिभावी the laws made by Parliament and the laws made by an 251 Parliament .
According to article 252 two or more State Legislatures by passing a resolution may ask Parliament to make laws on any matter in the State List .
Such laws can be extended to other States provided the concerned State Legislatures pass resolutions to that effect .
Articles 256 to 265 seek to regulate administrative relations between the Union and the States .
It is common in federal systems that the administrative relations between the Union and the States are fraught with difficulties.
The Constitution of India seeks to achieve a smooth working relationship between the two levels .
It provides that the executive powers of the State Government are to be exercised in such a way as to ensure compliance with the laws made by Parliament .
The executive of the Union is also empowered to give directions to the States which appear to the Government of India to be necessary for the purpose .
Under article 258 the President may with the consent of a State Government entrust to that Government or its officers functions in relation to any subject to which the executive power of the Union extends .
Similarly under article 258 ) the Governor of a State may with the consent of the Government of India entrust to that Government or to its officers functions in relation to any matter to which the executive power of the State is extended .

Borrowing Union ' s executive power is that Parliament can borrow from the Consolidated Fund of India within the limits prescribed by law ( articles 292 ) .
A State may also similarly borrow subject to limits set by the Legislature .
The Government of India can within its borrow powers lend to any State or guarantee loans raised by the State .

The Union and the executive power of every State shall extend to carrying on trade or business and to acquire hold or dispose of property and make contracts subject to any law made by the concerned State Legislature ( article विधानमंडल ) .
This article says obviously is an independent or additional source of executive power in addition to article 245 .
The Supreme Court in न्यायालय v . state of Uttar Pradesh ( AIR 1974 ) decided that the power of the state under Article व्यापार means that trade can be done in other states ( see Maharashtra ) .
In the Supreme Court of India ( AIR 1967 SC 1967 ) the verdict in the Supreme Court case held that the principle of natural justice should be applied to the decision to review the order of detention .
During the proclamation of internal emergency ( 1975 - 77 ) the approach of the Supreme Court to cases of violation of Fundamental Rights vis - a - vis emergency provisions has been significantly changed .
In the event of the habeas corpus बंदी the बंदी Court refused to interfere in the case of detention of persons as it held out the clear intention that preventive detention was controlled exclusively by the Executive .
In the Union of India ( AIR 1977 SC 359 ) the court held that all rights of personal liberty could be suspended during national emergency due to Presidential orders under articles 19 359 and 22 .
Most of these Court pronouncements ended validity after the 44th amendment inter alia amended articles 352 358 and 359 .
The entire expenses of the Union and State Service Commissions are charged on the Consolidated Fund of the Union or the Consolidated Fund of the concerned State ( articles 322 ) .
The Chairman and members of the Public Service Commissions are appointed by the President or the Governor as the case may be .
No government department or officer can therefore refuse to entertain a representation on the ground that he is not in the official language .
In - depth studies of the language provisions particularly in Article 343 344 and 351 would show that the ultimate objective is the spread and development of Hindi and the gradual use of it as a link language for official purposes .
There will be no breach of article 351 in case of the use of English even after the period of 15 years ; but under article 343 Parliament has been given the power to observe the progress of Hindi as the Official Language Act .

The Court held that the order violated Article 351 in as much as it excited the feeling of opposition to Hindi instead of promoting Hindi .
The authoritative Hindi text of the Constitution has since been published .

The existing Indian constitutional system was further changed by the 1919 Act and the rules made under it .
The Central Legislative Council replaced it by a bicameral legislature consisting of a Council of State ( High House ) and a Lower House .
There is no limitation on the power to amend . There is no provision in the Constitution which cannot be amended .
The fundamental rights guaranteed under the Constitution ( Part III ) are subject to the Parliamentary power of the Constitution - LRB - Amendment - RRB - .
In the Golak Nath case the Supreme Court overruled its earlier decisions by a six - set majority and stated that the fundamental rights are छीन in the Constitution - LRB - article 368 without any amendment to the Constitution or article 13 .
In 1973 in the गोलकनाथ Bharti v. State of Kerala ( AIR 1973 SC गोलकनाथ ) the Supreme Court reviewed the decision of the Golak Nath case .
Ten of the 13 judges held that Article 368 itself contained the power to amend the Constitution and that the law of Article 13 ( 2 ) did not absorb the constitutional amendment under article 368 .
The law declared in Golak Nath case was accordingly उलट .
As to whether the power of amendment under article 368 was arbitrary and infinite ; the seven judges decided by a large majority of the judges that the power of amendment under article 368 was subject to the limitation involved .
But what the infrastructure is ( and does not make it clear by the majority and the question remains controversial .
In the संसद case after this decision the Constitution ( 44th Amendment ) Act . 1976 added to it clauses 4 and 5 to the and reduced the limitation of the powers to amend Parliament .

While introducing the Draft Constitution in the Constituent Assembly on 4 November 1948 and recommending the parliamentary system शासन Chairman of the Drafting Committee said that " the Draft Constitution ' s pattern was more स्थिरता than the शासन system .
Though some sounds were heard against the idea of a parliamentary system the proposal of the Drafting Committee was in overwhelming majority and finally the Constitution of the Republic of free India was established on 26 January 1950 with the establishment of a modern institutional structure and other .
The three word राजनीतिक representative राजनीतिक parliamentary and democracy are the basic features of our political system .
After every general election to the Lok Sabha the President at the commencement of the first session and at the commencement of the first session of each year addresses the Houses of Parliament assembled together and informs reasons for inviting the Houses of Parliament together .
Further he may address either House of Parliament or both Houses assembled together and for that purpose require the attendance of members .
He has the power to send सेदश or any other message to the House with respect to a Bill that is pending in Parliament the House shall revert to the notice of the House which may be required to be considered by the House .
Some Bills may be introduced only after the recommendation of the President has been examined or proceeded further .
There are certain other functions of Parliament as per the Constitution which are expected to be discharged by the President .
Whenever necessary he appoints a Speaker of the Speaker and the Executive Chairman of the Rajya Sabha a temporary ( Pro - सभा ) of Lok Sabha .
It is for him to have a joint sitting in case of disagreement between the two Houses on a Bill .
Every year the budget of the Government . referred to as the Annual Financial Statement in the Constitution - LRB - C - RRB - of the Union and the Comptroller and Auditor General - General of India - RRB - is special report to the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes as to Parliament and to the Scheduled Tribes .
If he is of the opinion that the Anglo - Indian community does not have adequate representation in the Lok Sabha he may nominate not more than two members for the House .
Other ministers are appointed by the President on the advice of the Prime Minister .
It may be mentioned here that the President does not often have the opportunity to exercise his personal will to appoint the prime minister .
However if a situation arises that no party gets a clear majority in the Lok Sabha the President may use his judgement to choose a leader who in his opinion is likely to command the support of the majority in the House .
The Prime Minister usually is a member of the Lok Sabha but the Ministers are drawn to both Houses of Parliament .
A person who is not a member of either House of Parliament has to vacate the office after six months unless in the meanwhile he manages to get himself elected to either House .
At the same time every minister holds office during the pleasure of the President and shall be liable to dismissal by him .
But since the President does so only on the advice of the prime minister this power actually rests with the prime minister .
The relationship between the Executive and the Legislature is one that is most intimate and ideally does not admit any antagonism or division .
The two are not visualised as competing centres of power but as inseparable partners or या in the business of competition .
The Council of Ministers may in a sense be described as the grand executive committee of the Parliament charged with the responsibility of governance on behalf of the parent body .
In other words the executive is not a separate or outside body .
There is however a clear distinction between the functions of the Executive and the functions of the Parliament .
The business of Parliament is to legislate advise criticise and ventilate public grievances .
The Executive is to govern albeit on behalf of the Parliament .
In the words of the first Secretary of the Indian Parliament :
" The Parliament should not take part in the responsibilities of the government at any time because once the Parliament has started doing so the responsibility of the Parliament and the Executive become vague and the Parliament does not exercise its full power of criticism .
Article 13 of the Constitution clearly prohibits the making of any law by Parliament the State Legislature or by any other authority which may be inconsistent with or in derogation of any of the fundamental rights contained in the Constitution .
226 confer power on the Supreme Court and the High Courts respectively for the enforcement of these rights .
Whether it is opposed to the provisions of the Constitution or the law हनन any of the fundamental rights .
It is sometimes assumed and often said that just as it is for the Legislature to make laws and for the Executive to execute them it is for the Courts to interpret the Constitution and the laws .
Such a possession is very misleading and false .
The Union is divided into States .
A law made by a State can be applicable only in the territory of that state .
The Union Parliament can make laws for the whole or any part of the territory of India .
Parliament also enjoys the power of extra - territorial legislation i . e . a law made by it shall be applicable not only to the people and property in the Indian territory but also to Indian citizens residing abroad .
The States do not have the power to legislate .
The Constitution provides for a three - fold distribution of legislative power between the Union and the States .
List I or the Union List contains 97 subjects over which the Parliament alone can legislate .
List II or the State List includes 66 entries over which State Legislatures have got exclusive power of legislation .
List III or the Concurrent List contains 47 items on which both the Parliament and the State Legislatures can make laws .
While in their respective spheres as allotted by the Constitution they enjoy complete autonomy the State Legislatures nevertheless the scheme of distribution of powers emphasises the general predominance of the Parliament in the legislative field .
The Parliament also has the power to legislate for implementing any decision made in the State List by the treaty agreement or convention with any country or on any matter in an international conference association or other body .
The Parliament may legislate even on some subject in the State List .
If two or more State Legislatures consider it desirable that any of the matters within their exclusive legislative competence should be regulated by parliamentary legislation and pass resolutions to that effect the Parliament can undertake the necessary legislation .
However the legislation so adopted is governed by those States who have requested and all the others to follow it by resolutions passed in that behalf .
Some of the entries in the Union List are also given power to Parliament to make the requisite declaration by secondary law to take over some regions and subjects from the territory of the State .
Parliament has the power to form a new State by separating its territory from any one State or by uniting two or more States .
( c ) can alter the boundaries of any state ; and ( d ) in the name of any state .
These changes are not like amendments to the Constitution but can be made by the Parliament by passing a Bill on the recommendation of the President .
Such a Bill is required to be referred to the legislatures of the States concerned for expressing their views thereon within the stipulated period .
But such a Bill by sending to the legislatures does not lose the power to make a change as it thinks fit .
है is said to be in another place .
The operative reality of politics today is that the power resides in the prime minister and his cabinet and not in Parliament .
The Prime Minister is the leader of the majority in the Lok Sabha and also the head of the government .
He may consult two or three colleagues and go ahead .
It is ultimately the prime minister who is responsible to the Parliament and the nation for the policies of the government . "
Administration is run by the permanent civil services .
The Parliament does not interfere with day - to - day administration nor does it control the administration .
Often the Press struggles hard to unearth the administrative lapses scandals and shortcomings gives expression to public grievances and difficulties and reports on how policies are being carried out .
Much of the information obtained from daily newspapers for parliamentary questions practical proposals and debates is an important instrument on which members depend .
Simultaneously the Press keeps the people informed of what is happening in Parliament .
This two - way traffic enables the Press to maintain an important and strong link between the public and the Parliament .
Considering the space that is devoted to these matters and the volume of information that is given the Press in our country fulfils a great need felt alike by the members of Parliament and the people .
Even though so much information from such a variety of sources is available to Parliament it is not enough.
The information supplied by the official government sources is efficiently collected and processed but it may sometimes consciously or unconsciously get पक्षपातपूर्ण or biased and may always be completely objective factual and objective .
Information from other sources like the mass media political parties interest groups or लॉबी would be even less so.
The government is sensitive to parliamentary opinion ; in most cases they anticipate it; they bow to it in some cases and in some cases they may feel that they cannot alter their convictions their responsibilities and political ideology .
However during discussions members have full liberty to criticise and suggest how they work in the future or how a particular measure may be carried out .
The discussions have affected the minds of the people on the administrative apparatus and if this does not happen the administration is unaware of the sentiments of the people .
Parliamentary debates serve to remind the administration of its duties and obligations .
Parliamentary debates effect the administrative thinking and action in a variety of ways and the subtle influence which cannot be measured in terms of any visible units .
When the administrators have complete freedom to implement the policies framed by the Parliament in the best manner possible however the various ideas expressed in the House have a deep influence and guidance to them .
And that may be called the Advisory Role of Parliament .
Conflict is natural to be a conflict in one ' s life conflict of ideas and interests and struggle for power by various contending forces .
Parliamentary democracy is considered to be a better and more civilized system of government inasmuch as under it debate and discussion on the legislative floor take the place of physical strife on the streets or on the battle fields .
This is especially so when charges are made against a person who has no opportunity to come before the House and explain his position .
Before entering on to ascertain the factual basis of such questions गृहीत may be referred to the ministries / departments concerned .
Members are also sometimes asked to supply material in support of the allegations made in the question .
Moreover where the subject matter of any question is pending for judgement before a court or any other tribunal or body constituted under law or before a Parliamentary Committee the matter is not permitted to be questioned .
It may be noted that questions should not relate to any matter which is not primarily related to the Government of India .
Questions that contain arguments inferences or defamatory statements or otherwise refer to the character or conduct of a person not in his official or public capacity but questions which instead of seeking information are given instead of questions .
The questions are put in starred or अतारांकित categories according to the conditions provided in the rules .
The Mission was in India from March 1946 to May 1946 .
The Mission rejected the demand for the creation of a separate sovereign state as it believed that there would be a large number of non - Muslims in Pakistan and the vast majority of Muslims would be left outside Pakistan .
The Cabinet Mission also rejected the Congress scheme of a loose federation as involving constitutional disadvantages and anomalies .
It recommended a three - tier structure consisting of the Indian Union of States Parties to the Central Provinces at the top and the Provinces and the रियासतों States .
The Cabinet Mission recommended that the Constitution should be in such a way that there should be a Union of India consisting of both the Indian States and which proceeded with regard to the following subjects : i . e . external affairs security and communication .
The Union should have an executive and legislative body representing British India and the princely states .
If there is a question raising a major communal issue in the Legislature it should be resolved by a majority of representatives present and voting from each of the two major communities and a majority of all the members present and voting .
All subjects and rights other than those entrusted to the Union shall vest in the States .
A provision should be made in the memorandum of the Union and the group by which any province can re - provide for a review of the Constitution after an initial period of 10 years from the majority of its Vidhan Sabha .
The Speaker / Chairman decides in every case whether the matter needs elucidation on a matter of fact and is of sufficient public importance to be put down for discussion .
The procedure in the House on such a discussion is that after the member who has initiated the discussion the discussion has given a brief statement showing more than four other members , who may ask an explanation for the said purpose .
Thereafter at the end the minister concerned चर्चा the discussion .
यद्यपि the Question Hour Though the purpose of asking questions as defined is to be known in actual practice most of the questions are to be provided information .
On the one hand parliamentary questions it is possible that Government associations who provide materials to their representatives for queries might be informed of their grievances their problems and responsibilities and their views on the other hand through the processes and programmes of the government .
Apart from the deterrent effect of parliamentary questions on public functionaries the questions bring to the notice of the Executive the way the policies are being implemented and how these affect the common people .
Amidst the proliferating machinery of modern government the political executive and even the administrative heads should be finding it difficult to know what is going on in their departments .
In this respect parliamentary questions are of course an aid to the Executive for they put into focus areas of vital concern to the public .
It can be safely said that members show great interest in using the right to ask questions .
It was therefore considered that some procedure might be devised whereby members might have an opportunity of bringing urgent matters to the attention of the government .
In the modern parliamentary procedure the idea of introducing Calling Attention Notices in the Rules of Procedure is purely an Indian innovation .
Added to this
Sometimes it gives opportunity to members to criticise the government directly or indirectly and to bring to the surface the failure or inadequate action of the government in an important matter .
A member with the previous permission of the Speaker / Chairman may draw the attention of a minister to a matter of urgent public importance and request him to make a statement on that matter .
The minister may make a short statement or ask for time to make a statement on a later date .
The members' chief source for होते the Calling Attention Notices is the daily newspapers .
Sometimes they may be based on the private information of a member or on the correspondence between him and his electorate .
Notices of Calling Attention have to be given by members in writing by 10. 00 .
A member cannot give two or more notices for a meeting .
Notices on the same subject may be given by more than one member but names of not more than five members are shown in the List of Business.
The Speaker goes through the notices and selects one of them for a statement by the concerned minister at the sitting of the House on the following day .
In some cases a , Chairman may select two such notices .
However if the Speaker feels that the matter is so urgent that a statement should be made by the minister on the same day he may in his discretion allow , to go on the same day as his notice has been given .
The idea behind admitting Calling Attention Notices a day or so in advance is that it would give sufficient time to the minister concerned to gather facts about the matter raised and prepare a statement in time .
No more than two notices can be taken up in a meeting to give the attention of the ministers .
There is no debate on such a statement but every member in whose name the matter is listed is permitted to ask a question for the clarification .
The main purpose of calling attention is therefore to seek an authoritative statement from a minister on a matter of urgent nature .
This process does not involve any censure against the government as there is no regular discussion and voting.
Among the subjects on which the ministers have been asked to furnish their terms : there are trouble in any part of India ; inter - district relations in any part of the country ; railway विमानों of all such decisions taken by the central government ;
While raising the point the सदस्य member is not permitted to deviate from the approved text of his statement .
The minister concerned writes to the member directly with regard to matters raised under Rule 377 informing him of the government views and the action taken in the matter .
It may be noted that matters so raised are not included in the List of Business .
Prior to the fourth Lok Sabha use of Rule 377 for raising matters in the House was somewhat restricted but a more liberal approach has been adopted to enable the members to raise various matters of public importance more particularly in the earliest possible cases .
It is found that members are increasingly taking recourse to this rule and this procedure has become very popular .
While during Fourth Lok Sabha only 36 matters were allowed to be raised under Rule 377 during the Fifth Plan the Sixth Seventh Lok Sabhas and Eighth Lok Sabhas such matters numbered 184 लोक सभा सभा and सभा respectively.

18 . If it is adopted it loses the original proposal and is not put to vote ; but if a decision is accepted the original question is put to be revised .
Subsidiary motion depends upon or relate to other motions or follow up on some proceedings in the House .
They have nothing in themselves and are not capable of stating the decision of the House without reference to the original motion or the proceedings of the House .

Resolutions moved by the ministers are generally intended to convey the approval of the House on such international treaties multilateral or agreements made by the government ; or to declare or approve of some national and international policies of the government .
( c ) The statutory resolutions may be moved by a minister and also by a private member .
They are known by the name because they are always brought in pursuance of a provision made in the Constitution or an Act of Parliament and certain Acts expressly require the government to introduce a resolution within a given period of time .
If a clause is inserted in that particular article of the Constitution or a section of the statute under which a statutory will be prescribed a period of time is not set for a statutory resolution to be moved .

Joint - sitting of the two Houses : A vote on a Bill arises on account of disagreement between the two Houses on a deadlock resulting in an extraordinary situation which the two Houses meet together .
Under the Constitution the President is empowered to summon the Bill if the Bill has not lapsed due to the dissolution of the Lok Sabha invites both Houses for the purpose of deliberation and vote of the House .
Such a joint - sitting is presided over by the Speaker who assists the Secretary - General the Lok Sabha लोक .
The Rules of Procedure of the House apply to a joint meeting .
At the joint - sitting only such amendments can be proposed which become necessary due to the delay in passing the Bill .
The decisions at such sittings are taken by the majority of the total number of members of both the Houses present and voting.
So far only two bills ( the Dowry Prohibition Bill 1961 and the Banking Service Commission ( Repeal ) were passed at joint - sitting .
( 5 ) assent to Bills when a Bill has been passed by both the Houses either singly or at a joint - sitting is presented to the President for his assent .
If the President . his assent there is an end to the Bill .
The Rajya Sabha cannot reject a Money Bill nor can it amend it by virtue of its own powers .
If any of the recommendations made by the Rajya Sabha are accepted by the Lok Sabha the Money Bill shall be deemed to have been passed by both the Houses with the recommendations accepted by the Rajya Sabha and accepted by the Lok Sabha .
If the Lok Sabha does not accept any of the recommendations made by the Rajya Sabha the Bill shall be deemed to have been passed by both the Houses in the form passed by the Lok Sabha before the amendments recommended by the Rajya Sabha .
In addition if any passed and a Money Bill passed to the Rajya Sabha for its recommendation is not passed by the Lok Sabha within the said period of 14 days .
There is no question of any disagreement between the two Houses with regard to a Money Bill as in the case of a simple Bill because it enjoys equal power with the Lok Sabha in the case of ordinary Bills .
Hence there is no provision for a joint - sitting in the case of a Money Bill .
financial
Generally speaking a Financial Bill means a Bill which relates to revenue or expenditure .
But being not a Money Bill the Financial Bill being a Money Bill the Council is fully empowered to reject or amend it as it does in the case of an ordinary Bill .
Except that there is no such amendment in the House except in the case of reduction of taxes and taxation without the recommendation of the President the dissolution of the Finance Bill lies in the House except in the case of a simple Bill a simple Bill in which it is agreed upon both the combined House .
The provision of a joint - sitting does not apply to the case of a Money Bill .
The Finance Bill of class B which inter alia contains one or more proposals from the Consolidated Fund of India and which excludes any matter mentioned in Article 110 may be regarded as a General Bill or for the same reasons .
It does not require the recommendation of the President for its introduction .
However the recommendation of the President is essential for its consideration by either House .
In other words it is not a condition that the President may recommend it before he does so in the case of a Money Bill or a Finance Bill but in this case unless a Bill is passed by the President .
In all other respects the procedure of such a Bill is the same as that of an ordinary Bill including the provision of a joint - sitting in case of disagreement between the two Houses .
The procedure for amendment of the Constitution ( Amendment ) Bill was laid down in Article 368 .
The Constitution does not provide for a separate constituent body . The power to amend the constitution is vested in Parliament .
A Bill for amending the Constitution may be introduced in either House of Parliament .
Such a Bill may be introduced by the government or by a private member .
Generally Constitution ( Amendment ) Bills brought forward by Ministers are introduced in the Lok Sabha .
Apart from being subject to ordinary rules applicable to Bills of a non - government member it is also necessary that a Committee on Private Members' Bills and Resolutions should examine and recommend for the introduction of a Bill in the House .
But it is not bound by the views so gained .
As a matter of custom a motion for leave to introduce a Bill of non - official member is not opposed .
If the motion for introduction is opposed on the ground that it is outside the legislative competence of the House the Chair may permit a full discussion thereon and thereafter put the motion for the decision of the House.
Ordinarily . a member can introduce four Bills in a session .
After a Bill is introduced in the Lok Sabha and before it is disposed of in the House the Committee on Private Members' Bills and Resolutions में the nature of the Bill and the category B .
In Lok Sabha the relative precedence of Bills in a particular category is determined by लोक .

In a parliamentary system the Legislature has to lay down the policies of the Government ; law - making work and oversee the administration to be monitored .
But the enormous range and complexity of legislation and administrative functions of a modern State make it almost impossible for the Legislature to adequately scrutinise legislative proposals and oversee administrative action .
While the government has vast and highly sophisticated administrative machinery and organisation manned by experts specialists and seasoned civil servants at its' disposal to undertake its complex tasks the Legislature finds itself severely handicapped .
Through parliamentary devices like questions and debates he can exercise very little control over the administration .
In order to make parliamentary surveillance more effective and meaningful the Parliament needs an agency which would trust the whole House .
This among other things the Parliament seeks to achieve through Parliamentary Committees composed of a small number of their members particularly in India .
The review of administrative action and the examination of numerous and complicated legislative proposals and subordinate legislation require expertise and close scrutiny that are not possible in the Lok Sabha consisting as it does of 545 members .
Ad hoc Committees Such Committees may be broadly put into two categories : ( a ) a Select or Joint Committee on Bills which may consider and report on particular Bills .
They differ from other ad hoc Committees to the effect that the Bills are referred to and the procedure followed by them is laid down by the Speaker in the light of the directions given to them by the Speaker or the Speaker in the particular case .
For instance a Committee was constituted in 1951 to go into the conduct of a member Shri H . G . Mudgal on a motion adopted by the लोक Lok Sabha .
Railway Convention Committee is appointed from time to time Joint Committee on Offices of Profit and any other Committee appointed by the House or by the Speaker or Chairman for some specific purpose are also other examples of such committees .
More recently important Joint Committees of the two Houses were formed on matters like salary allowances and pension समितियां for members the Bofors Gun Deal . the Bank Securities सौदा .
The Committees are constituted by members of the सदन Committees nominated by the House by proposing a motion or elected or by the Speaker or Chairman as the case may be deemed to be .
Select Joint Committees on a Bill are appointed on a motion adopted by the House .
All Financial Committees ( i . e . Public Accounts Committee . Estimates Committee on Public Undertakings ; . Committee on Public Undertakings , members of the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes are elected by the members every year in accordance with the system of proportional representation .
The remaining Committees are nominated by the Presiding Officer of the House .
While some of the Committees are constituted by each House separately others are constituted jointly by both the Houses .

The Estimates Committee deals with estimates of public expenditure the धन and Public Accounts Committee deals with the accounts it is intended to ensure that the expenditure made by the House is allocated by the House for the purposes of which it is authorised by the Parliament .

Parliamentary Museum and Archives India has always accorded maximum importance to parliamentary institutions.
Of late . efforts are being made to harness all necessary resources for collecting and preserving for the present and future generations the country ' s rich heritage .
A beginning was made in 1976 when the Lok Sabha Secretariat set up a Parliamentary Archives of संसदीय and Films to preserve an authentic comprehensive complete and up - to - date pictorial record of the history of the institution of Parliament its activities and personalities.
A proposal for setting up a Parliamentary Museum and Archives was approved by the General Purposes Committee of the Lok Sabha on 1 August 1984 .
The basic purpose of the Parliamentary Museum and Archives is to secure from the present era of the Constitution and Parliament and all the precious records of the past the historical documents and objects from political accounts and institutions for the future generations through which they must have been destroyed .
At the current stage of its development it is concentrating on acquisition and building of comprehensive collections proper preservation of all its holdings and display of selected materials .
In due course it proposes to undertake other tasks devoted to dissemination of information on parliamentary institutions and the projection of a proper image of the Parliament by stimulating interest in its growth activities and its achievements .

The basic characteristics of democracy are that of the people irrespective of their caste creed caste creed colour or sex or creed and beyond discrimination of the individual and economy which they may think fit into the law and which every individual is to declare .
In a democracy the people are supposed to be their own master .
They have an inalienable right to rule themselves or to be ruled in the way they like and by the people they choose .
Democracy also recognises the fact that from time immemorial human beings have been fighting with each other for power or for supremacy.
Democracy tries to substitute a more civilised manner of fighting.
It represents ways and means of संघर्ष the armed conflict .
In ancient Indian Village Republics and the Greek City States all the citizens assembled together and decided issues of governance .
From the British Commonwealth it became the Commonwealth of Nations .
The Commonwealth specifically recognised India ' s position as a sovereign independent republic .
It has therefore no bearing on the sovereign democratic or republican nature of the State .
Social and economic democracy : Democracy conceived merely from a political point of view is that every citizen has the right to freely vote in elections which are at regular times .
The 'one man one man one वोट principle applied in all democratic elections emanated from the recognition of equal rights to all men - whether highly educated or illiterate industrialists or labourers.
For our founding fathers however democracy did not mean merely political democracy or the people ' s right to periodically vote to elect their representatives .
Without social and economic democracy political democracy had no meaning in a poor country like India .
Dr .
Ambedkar social and economic democracy was the real aim and ultimate goal .
He said that parliamentary democracy was meaningless unless it was geared to achieving the real goal of economic democracy .
Jawaharlal Nehru had observed later that Democracy of his conception was only a means to an end.
The end is that everyone has a quality life which needs some essential economic needs .
As democracy succeeds in solving the economic problems in the same measure it succeeds in the political field .
If the economic problems are not solved then the political structure tends to weaken and crack .
It is clarified by the words of the Preamble which speak of securing " social justice to all citizens of the Republic .
Justice means व्यक्तियों of interests between the individuals between the individuals between groups and those of individuals on the one hand and those of the community on the other .
Most significantly the Preamble places Justice higher than the other principles of Liberty Equality and fraternity .
The concept of Justice in the Preamble is indeed very wide .
It is not confined to the narrow legal justice as administered by courts .
Social justice implies that all citizens are treated as equal and their status in society is no consideration in matters of justice because of birth caste creed race caste sex creed sex - respect sex title etc.
Article 15 prohibits discrimination or disability in the matter of access to public places .
Social justice is the aim of all the provisions relating to humane conditions of work maternity relief leisure promoting economic interests and the relaxation of the deprived classes the relaxation of forced labour and so on .
Economic justice is expected to treat rich and poor in a way and to bridge the gap between them .
In pursuance of the objective of economic justice - LRB - article 39 - RRB - directed the State to ensure that adequate means of livelihood to citizens are not provided by adequate means of livelihood to ensure that children are not given equal rights and so on .
In fact various other articles in Part IV of the Constitution ( articles 36 to 51 ) are also directed towards securing a new social and economic order imbued with justice .
The concept embodied in our Preamble is only that of equality of status and opportunity .
Legal matters are social security political and economic aspects .
All citizens are equal before law and enjoy equal protection of the laws of the country .
All citizens are equally entitled to enjoy the political rights to vote and participate in the process of governance .
Equality in economic sector means a simultaneous salary for one ' s ability and work .
Further का will not exploit one man or one class other persons or classes .
The concept of equality of status and opportunity has been given concrete substance and shape in articles 14 to 18 .
न्याय justice equality is relevant and meaningful in so far as they promote the brotherhood of Indian fraternity the son of a single Mother India and it promote the idea of communal harmony religious and many other जातीय .
Provisions relating to common citizenship are directed towards strengthening Indian fraternal feelings and building a strong Indian brotherhood .
The fundamental rights guaranteed to all citizens without any discrimination and the Directive Principles directed at achieving social and economic equality are also designed to promote fraternity .
It goes beyond separation of religion and politics freedom of religion equality of respect for all religions etc .
Unfortunately not enough importance has been given to the concept by न्यायाधीशों न्यायाधीशों and judges .

In the Chalukya - Rashtrakuta series in the Deccan and in those that took after them the mandapa is of two types .
In the first case the central part is divided into a स्तंभों containing the peripheral round of small and thick pillars corresponding to the upper pillars .

The Pallava - Pandya series of temples and what followed them in material technique and tradition in the succeeding periods in the farther south elaborated the shape from the square to the oblong by emphasizing linear rows of taller pillars with wider sweep .
All this resulted in such multi - pillared mandapas as the hundred - or thousand - pillared mandapas .

Savarkar ' s trial in The Hague the court of Arbitration vs. Great Britain before the court and the trial in India were landmarks in contemporary legal and political history .
During his stay in London for five years he did not take any action publicly against British laws but his participation in political activities irked the British Government which was searching for grounds for action against them .
The British adopted a dubious method to suppress their voice and curb their activities .
Savarkar was proclaimed a fugitive an offender for his political activities by the Indian Government who wrote to the British Government to भेजने him to India to face trial .
Savarkar who had gone to England as a student on a regular passport to England was charged under the इंग्लैंड . Act 1881 .
In an unprecedented step the British Government issued a warrant for his arrest from the Bow Street court London on 22nd February 1910 .
( i ) To war against His Majesty the King or to introduce war ;
( 2 ) The conspiracy to deprive His Majesty of the sovereignty of British India or a part of it .
( 3 ) Collecting and distributing arms and हत्या the killing of Jackson .
He was arrested in England in 1910 for the so - called speeches delivered in India in 1906 .
He was produced in the Bow Street police court on 14th March 1910 .
After a few पुलिस on April 20 the magistrate refused to release him on bail and Savarkar was transferred from Bow Street police custody to इंग्लैंड Jail in England awaiting further orders for his transportation to India to stand trial.
Mr सावरकर counsel for Savarkar made an application for a writ of habeas corpus and also appealed against the decision of the Bow Street court .
The habeas corpus application and appeal were heard on 2nd and 3rd June 1910 by the Divisional Court .
The presiding judge upheld the decision of the Bow Street court and rejected the petition .
Again an appeal was filed in the High Court but Mr सावरकर Williams the Chief Justice of the British High Court endorsed the decision of the ब्रिटिश Court endorsed Savarkar allowing him to give him the case to be instituted in India by a special ordinance .
Justice Coleridge who was in minority असहमति and held that Savarkar should not be sent to India but the majority view affirmed his transportation to India .
Savarkar was kept in custody till July 1910 in the British jail and preparations were made to send him to India to try his case against him .

Effects on Human Health It is proved beyond doubt that polluted air is highly detrimental to human health and is a contributory factor in deaths from diseases such as lung cancer .
Air pollution is mostly associated with respiratory diseases ranging from common cold to lung cancer .
Both gaseous and particulate pollutants cause severe damage to the respiratory system leading to श्वसनी bronchitis and asthma.
और air irritates the eyes and some pollutants like lead tend to accumulate in the body at times to dangerous levels.
Deaths from lung cancer are increasing and the prime causative agent is suspected to be polluted air .

This ignominious trial also brought to an end both the Mughal Empire in India and the East India Company .

Sri Aurobindo ( 1872 - 1872 - 1872 Aurobindo Ghose ) was born on 15 August 1872 .
His father पिता Ghose ( 1845 - 1893 ) came of the well - known Ghose family of West Bengal .
When Aurobindo was seven years old अरविंद his father and his two elder brother इंग्लैंड इंग्लैंड and Manmohan were taken to England .
He had his early education in an English family .
When he joined the St. Paul ' s School in London as a scholar he had already learnt Latin and read on his own Shakespeare and the romantic poets .
He learnt French and Italian and Spanish to read Goethe Dante and Dante in the original language .
At the age of eleven he had begun writing poetry in Greek Latin ani English .
As a secretary to the Indian Majlis Cambridge University he made revolutionary speeches hinting at armed rebellion as the only way to India ' s freedom .
Though he had passed the Indian Civil Service Examination he did not join it and returned to India in 1893 with an appointment in the Baroda State Service .
He spent thirteen years in approaching the post of Acting Principal of the State College at Baroda .
He learnt Sanskrit drama and Sanskrit and acquired the knowledge of the epics the बांग्ला the Upanishads and Sanskrit literature; wrote poetry plays and essays in English .
He had returned to Calcutta as Principal of the newly formed National College ( now Jadavpur ) .
Aurobindo directed the revolutionary workers to utilise the partition for expanding their activities .
He directed नेशनलिस्टों to his policy and organisation and to start the famous daily अंग्रेजी and joined the English daily of Bipin Chandra Pal .
He published in the ” Bande Mataram का sequence of articles on' The Doctrine of Passive Resistance ' प्रतिरोध out the right method of execution of the nationalist programme of ' Swadeshi ' and ' boycott ' .
In August 1907 Aurobindo was arrested for certain articles published in the बंदे बंदे ' but the charge failed because it could not be proved that he was the editor of that letter .
In May 1908 he was arrested along with 38 other revolutionaries where he spent one year as a " क्रांतिकारियों " before release .
In jail he had the realisation of cosmic consciousness and he had the vision of Sri Krishna everywhere and he had the assurance of India' s freedom and of his release for the good of the world .
After his release in May 1909 Aurobindo resumed his mission adding that he wrote articles on the true significance of Indian nationalism in two newly - born " कर्मयोगी " English " and " बांग्ला " .
One evening in February 1910 he received information that his office would be searched the next day and he would be arrested .
Following his inner voice he left for Chandernagore and then for Pondicherry where he completely withdrew from all political activities and devoted himself entirely to literature and philosophy .
He received the assistance of an enlightened French फ्रांसिसी Paul Richard and his wife ( who later became famous as the Mother ) at Pondicherry on the eve of the First World War .
In 1926 Aurobindo retired into seclusion which was till his death in 1950 .

The Meerut conspiracy case exposed the true face of British imperialism against organised opposition or dissent which had challenged the political and economic superiority of the established order .
In fact it was a determined effort to crush the organised labour movement and Marxist influence in India as all the major industries and operations were dominated by the British .
The period 1928 - 1929 was significant in Indian history for it was the beginning of an organised left - wing movement ( all economic and political components ) .
The organisation of trade unions enabled the workers to express their grievances and strive for better working conditions .
Though the Communist Party of India had been active for some time in India the movement could not gain any significance till 1927 .
It was only after 1927 - 29 that during the 1929 - 29 the communists made considerable headway in their efforts to infiltrate the trade unions and the labour organisation and to win over the youth force and a powerful section of the nationalist elite.
Even some British citizens were contributing their active part in the movement .
Soon the British Government became alarmed and undertook a series of legislative and administrative steps to nip the movement in the bud.
The most important and repressive measures were the वामपंथी of launching a mass conspiracy case against the prominent left - wing trade leaders which greatly impressed the future of the Communist Party of India and the entire left movement of the country .
The Government of India was in continuous correspondence with the British Government in England and was taking instructions to adopt legislative and punitive practices .

The Government of India promulgated an Ordinance on May 1 1992 .
The ordinance entrusted the trial of the trial to a Special Tribunal like the one which tried the मुकदमे during the First World War to be constituted by the High Court Judges of the High Court of Lahore under the Chairmanship of the High Court .
The Tribunal was invested with special powers to deal with wilful obstacle .
It suggested that all cases pending in the court of Rai Sahib Pandit Sri Kishan first - class magistrate of Lahore against any of the 24 persons would be tried by the Tribunal to be constituted under Section 4 .
The Chief Justice of the High Court would constitute a Tribunal for the above cases consisting of three persons who at that time were judges of the High Court .
The Chief Justice of the High Court shall consist of the chairman and the tribunal shall be entitled to make a legally authorised punishment for any offence committed by him .
Even if death sentence was passed he would not need the approval of the High Court as provided in the Code of Criminal Procedure .
If one of the accused deliberately सामने before the Tribunal or is engaged in the conduct of his muscle or any subsequent उपद्रवी of the case the accused shows his उपद्रवी and उपद्रवी conduct in that case even at any stage .
The decision of the Tribunal was final and conclusive and no order or sentence of the court could be appealed under the provisions of the Nyaya Code or the other judicial law existing or if anything of any authority.
Not only that the High Court had no right to reconsider any such order or sentence or to transfer the case further from the Tribunal to such a law or order or to take any further action relating to the ordinance .
This was an extraordinary procedure and the result was a foregone conclusion .

Sheikh Muhammad Abdullah Sheikh Muhammad Abdullah was born on 5th December 1905 in श्रीनगर a suburb of Srinagar .
His father died a fortnight before his birth leaving behind a widow . six sons and two daughters .
The family was पश्मीना with a modest था shawl trade .
Sheikh Abdullah got his matriculation from the Government High School at Srinagar and in 1930 from the Aligarh Muslim University passed his M. Sc. in Physics .
Early life of Sheikh Abdullah was influenced by Islamic teachings and history through his धर्मपरायण religious mother and elder brother .
Poet Iqbal also made a great impression .

In 1930 Sheikh Abdullah organised the " Young - Man Muslim Association " to campaign for better representation of Muslims in government jobs .
Later he joined the Government High School Srinagar as a science teacher but continued his political activities for which he was soon dismissed.
He got the first political recognition and when he was included in a committee of seven prominent Kashmiri Muslims ( on 8th July 1931 ) a large crowd outside the court was shot by the police against the same incident .
Sheikh Abdullah was first arrested on 21st September 1931 .
He was elected president of the " Muslim Conference formed in October 1932 .
In early 1939 it was converted into the National Conference of which he remained the President till 1953 except for the years 1942 and 1944 .
In May 1946 he was sentenced to nine years' imprisonment to challenge the 'Quit India' कारावास movement and the right of the Maharaja on Kashmir .
After his release on 29th September 1947 he declared that the people alone and not the ruler could decide the future of his state .
Sheikh Abdullah mobilised popular resistance against the raiders and support for accession of the State to India .
On 31 October 1947 he was the President of the Emergency Administration and on 5th March 1948 made the Prime Minister of the state .
In June 1949 he joined the Constituent Assembly of India .
He was one of the signatories to the Constitution a misunderstanding between the Indian leaders and Sheikh Abdullah culminated in his dismissal and arrest on 9th August 1953 as he was suspected of seeking a थे from India .
He assumed the role of a mediator between India and Pakistan in their dispute over Kashmir but his attitude regarding Kashmir ' s association with India was extremely complicated .
